{{Infobox model|name=|image=|image_size=|alt=|caption=Dimash Adilet in 2018|native_name=|native_name_lang=|birth_name=Dimash Adilet|birth_date={{Birth date and age|1995|5|17|mf=yes}}|birth_place=[[Almaty, Kazakhstan]]|death_date=<!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|birth YYYY|birth MM|birth DD}} -->|death_place=|death_cause=|residence=[[Geneva, Switzerland]]|nationality=|other_names=|citizenship=|alma_mater=[[Harvard University]]|occupation={{hlist|Businessman|Model|Social Media Influencer}}|years_active=|known_for=|spouse=<!-- {{marriage|name|start|end}} -->|partner=<!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' -->|children=|parents=|relatives=|height=180 cm|hair_color=Brown|eye_color=Brown|agency=|module=|website=<!-- {{URL|website}} -->}} Dimash Adilet ({{IPAc-en|dj|ɪ|ˈ|m|ɑː|ʃ}}; born May 17, 1995) is a Swiss-Kazakh [[Businessperson|businessman]], [[Male model|model]], and social media [[Influencer marketing|influencer]]. Dimash is one of the richest young men of [[Kazakhstan]] and is an heir to the fortune of one of Kazakhstan's wealthiest families.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1683601-dimash-adilet-biografiya-roditeli.html|title=Димаш Адилет: биография и родители|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.therichest.com/expensive-lifestyle/money/12-outrageous-rich-kid-instagram-accounts-you-need-to-follow/|title=12 Outrageous Rich Kids Instagram Accounts You Need to Follow|last=|first=|date=|work=TheRichest|access-date=2018-11-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.townandcountry.ph/people/money-power/10-real-life-crazy-rich-asians-a1934-20170805-lfrm2?utm_source=Facebook-TC&utm_medium=Ownshare&utm_campaign=20170805-fbnp-money-power-rich-asians-fbfirst|title=9 Real-Life Crazy Rich Asians|last=|first=|date=|work=Town and Country Magazine|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wolipop.detik.com/foto-entertainment/d-4220047/tajir-dari-lahir-inilah-sosok-si-ganteng-dimash-putra-konglomerat/4|title=Tajir Dari Lahir! Inilah Sosok Si Ganteng Dimash, Putra Konglomerat|last=|first=|date=|work=Detik.com|access-date=2018-11-25|language=Indonesian}}</ref> Adilet is an alumni of [[Harvard University]] and is known to be the first [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] member of [[Mensa International]], with a reported [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] of over 150 (over 99th percentile on the [[Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford-Binet intelligence scales]])<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://tengrinews.kz/kazakhstan_news/kazahstanets-voshel-v-chislo-samyih-umnyih-lyudey-na-planete-292199/|title=Казахстанец вошел в число самых умных людей на планете|website=Tengrinews.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.zakon.kz/4785332-kazakhstanskogo-dendi-dimasha-adilenta.html|title=Казахстанского денди Димаша Адилета пригласили в клуб умнейших людей планеты|website=Zakon.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1093945-camogo-zavidnogo-zhenikha-kazakhstanca-p.html|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана попал в клуб умнейших людей планеты|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://comode.kz/post/nashi-za-rubezhom/chem-zhivet-kazahstanets-v-zheneve-10-interesnyh-myslej-dimasha-adileta/|title=Чем живет казахстанец в Женеве: 10 интересных мыслей Димаша Адилета {{!}} женский портал Comode|last=|first=|date=|website=Comode.kz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://informburo.kz/novosti/zavidnyy-zhenih-iz-kazahstana-priznan-odnim-iz-samyh-umnyh-lyudey-v-mire.html|title=Завидный жених из Казахстана признан одним из самых умных людей в мире|last=|first=|date=|work=InformBuro.kz|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Dimash is known for his activity on the social media platform [[Instagram]], where he shares content with an audience of around 1 million people. He is one of the most followed male influencers in [[Switzerland]] and [[Kazakhstan]], cooperating with such brands as [[Audemars Piguet]] and [[Lamborghini]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3368810/Meet-rich-boys-Instagram-spend-40-000-night-hotel-suites-500-000-bags-shoes.html|title=Meet the rich boys of Instagram who spend thousands on bags and shoes|last=|first=|date=|work=Mail Online (Dailymail.co.uk)|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://cosmo.kz/dimash-adilet-o-sebe-i-svoem-otnoshenii-k-devushkam/|title=Димаш Адилет о себе и своем отношении к девушкам|last=|first=|date=|work=Cosmopolitan Magazine|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref> Dimash is an avid collector of luxury watches, cars, and motorcycles.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://firstclasse.com.my/rich-heirs-on-instagram-dimash-adilet/|title=Rich Heirs on Instagram: Dimash Adilet, Kazakhstan’s top Internet personality|last=|first=|date=|work=FirstClasse|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2016/02/odin-iz-15-samyh-populyarnyh-kazahstantsev-dimash-adilet/|title=Один из 15 самых популярных казахстанцев: Димаш Адилет - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> In 2016, he was named as one of the "50 most successful men on the internet" by [[L'Officiel Hommes]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hommes.kz/blog/2016/05/24/lofficiel-hommes-sovmestno-s-hackett-london-predstavlyayut-50-uspeshnyh-muzhchin-v-seti/|title=Hackett London представляет "50 успешных мужчин в сети"|last=|first=|date=|website=L'Officiel Hommes|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Due to his extravagant lifestyle and the attention he receives online from the members of the opposite sex, the media nicknamed Dimash as "The Real-Life [[Christian Gray|Christian Grey]]" and "Kazakhstan's [[Eligible bachelor|Most Eligible Bachelor]]".<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntk.kz/ru/revu/2017-03-07/samyj-zavidnyj-zhenix-kazaxstana-dimash-adilet-dal-sovety-kak-ugodit-devushke-364|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана Димаш Адилет дал советы, как угодить девушке|last=|first=|date=|website=НТК Channel|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2016/02/kazahstanskij-kristian-grej/|title=Казахстанский Кристиан Грей - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1409697-samyy-zhelannyy-zhenikh-kazakhstana-rask.html|title=Самый желанный жених Казахстана раскритиковал День святого Валентина|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-25|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://express-k.kz/news/shoubiz/instagram_zvezda_dimash_adilet_pokazal_50_ottenkov_serogo_v_gonkonge-127166|title=Инстаграм-звезда Димаш Адилет показал 50 оттенков серого в Гонконге|last=|first=|date=|website=express-k.kz|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://365info.kz/2018/08/otechestvennuyu-barbi-i-kazahstanskogo-kristiana-greya-nazvali-samoj-krasivoj-paroj/|title=Отечественную Барби и казахстанского Кристиана Грея назвали самой красивой парой - 365info.kz|last=|first=|date=|website=365info.kz|language=ru-KZ|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref>
Dimash speaks fluently in [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]], and currently resides in [[Geneva|Geneva, Switzerland]].<ref name=":2" />
== Early life and Education == Dimash Adilet was born on May 17, 1995, in [[Almaty|Almaty, Kazakhstan]]. He is the eldest son in the family.
At the age of 11, Dimash was sent to study in a private boarding school in [[Gstaad|Gstaad, Switzerland]], away from his family.<ref name=":0" /> In 2010 he attended a private boarding school and sports academy [[IMG Academy]] in [[Bradenton, Florida]] for a year, before returning to [[Switzerland]] to graduate from high school. Dimash is an alumni of [[Harvard University]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> His academic background is in [[Finance]] and [[Psychology]].<ref name=":13" />
During his school years, Dimash was competing in Swiss National [[Giant slalom|Ski Racing]] competitions, and at the age of 14, he passed the qualification for the skill-level of a professional Swiss ski instructor. Dimash was a decorated member of his high school's [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] team. He also engaged in [[Boxing|competitive boxing]] since the age of 14.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":12" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1758364-samyj-zelannyj-zenih-kazahstana-opisal-svou-budusuu-zenu.html|title=Самый желанный жених Казахстана описал свою будущую жену|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://food.detik.com/foto-kuliner/d-4227343/mengintip-anak-konglomerat-kazakhstan-dimas-adilet-saat-masak-dan-kulineran/9/#photos|title=Mengintip Anak Konglomerat Kazakhstan, Dimas Adilet Saat Masak dan Kulineran|last=|first=|date=|work=DetikFood|access-date=2018-11-27|language=Indonesian}}</ref>
He has been noted to have constantly gotten into fights at school, although always forgiven thanks to his outstanding academic performance.<ref name=":2" />
== Career == [[File:Dimash Adilet and Stefano Domenicali.jpg|thumb|right|Dimash Adilet and [[Lamborghini]] CEO [[Stefano Domenicali]]]] Dimash Adilet currently has around 1 million followers across his social media profiles. He first started gaining popularity on [[Instagram]] in 2015 for sharing snapshots of his luxury lifestyle and "refined" sense of fashion<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/rkoi-rich-kids-instagram-documentary-shows-lavish-lives/story?id=35917467|title=#RKOI: Film Documents Lavish Lives of Wealthy Youth|last=|first=|date=|website=ABC News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>, along with [[Philosophy|philosophical]] writing and inspirational captions on the subjects such as life, love, staying positive and treating each other with respect.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" /> With his online content, he is aiming to motivate the younger generation and act as a [[role model]] to encourage [[Personal development|personal]] and [[Intelligence|intellectual]] growth of the youth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tengrinews.kz/cinema/kazahstantsa-priglasili-snyatsya-britanskom-filme-Instagram-278345/|title=Казахстанца пригласили сняться в британском фильме об Instagram|website=Tengrinews.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> Dimash is also known to often promote positive social impact and advocate for [[environmental protection]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kaz.nur.kz/838153-qazaq-zhigiti-aghylshyn-filmine-tusuge.html|title=Қазақ жігіті ағылшын фильміне түсуге шақырту алды (фото)|last=NUR.KZ|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=kk-KZ}}</ref>
In 2016, Dimash became the first [[Kazakhs|Kazakh]] member of [[Mensa International]], after scoring in the upper 99th percentile ([[Stanford–Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford-Binet intelligence scales]]) on an official supervised IQ test, recording an [[Intelligence quotient|IQ]] of over 150. This lead to widespread news coverage of the topic in Kazakhstan and a subsequent increase in Dimash's online following.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":2" /> Other big increases in his following are attributed to various TV appearances, magazine photoshoots, media coverage, and organic follower growth.
Dimash's social media influence led to him cooperating with such brands as [[Audemars Piguet]] and [[Lamborghini]], among others. As a fashion [[Influencer marketing|influencer]], and a model, he often travels to [[Fashion week|Fashion Week]] events around the world, as well as other high-profile events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gaytimes.co.uk/style/99643/spotted-the-best-dressed-boys-at-lfw/|title=Spotted: The best dressed boys at London Fashion Week|date=2018-02-19|work=Gay Times|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-5270829/Rich-Kids-Instagram-beat-Blue-Monday.html|title=Rich Kids of Instagram show how they beat Blue Monday|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref>
Dimash Adilet is also engaged in his [[family business]] as well as his personal business.<ref name=":0" />
== Personal Life == In 2015, Dimash was reportedly involved in a short-lasting relationship with [[Miss Universe]] 2014 [[Paulina Vega]] after her visit to Kazakhstan, documented on both Adilet's and Vega's [[instagram]] accounts.
He is currently not married. Because of Dimash's young age, fame, and wealth, the media often refer to him as "Kazakhstan's Most [[Eligible bachelor|Eligible Bachelor]]" and "The Real-Life [[Christian Grey]]".<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nur.kz/1093967-shikarnaya-zhizn-samogo-zhelannogo-zheni.html|title=Шикарная жизнь самого желанного жениха Казахстана|last=|first=|date=|work=NUR.KZ|access-date=2018-11-26|language=ru-RU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zakon.kz/4844275-samyjj-zavidnyjj-zhenikh-kazakhstana.html#|title=Самый завидный жених Казахстана раскритиковал День Святого Валентина|website=Zakon.kz|language=ru|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> He has been cited by many sources to be [[Physical attractiveness|physically attractive]], and is said to receive a lot of female attention on his social media profiles.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":13" /> When asked how important it is for a man to be good-looking, during an interview for the [[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan Magazine]], Dimash stated: "Looks are subjective and looks are by far not what's most important for a man. A man should be intelligent, educated, honest, confident, dependable, and generous. Looks only come after all of these."<ref name=":2" />
Dimash is cited to consider family and healthy relationships to be central to a man's happiness. He also strongly dislikes the idea of [[infidelity]]. <ref name=":2" />
== References == <references />

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Douglas Henderson |honorific-suffix = |image = |office = [[Scottish National Party|Depute Leader of the Scottish National Party]] |leader = [[Gordon Wilson (Scottish politician)|Gordon Wilson]] |term_start = 1979 |term_end = 1981 |predecessor = [[Margo MacDonald]] |successor = [[Jim Fairlie]] |leader1 = [[William Wolfe]] |term_start1 = 1971 |term_end1 = 1973 |predecessor1 = [[George Leslie (politician)|George Leslie]] |successor1 = [[Gordon Wilson (Scottish politician)|Gordon Wilson]] |office2 = [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[East Aberdeenshire (UK Parliament constituency)|East Aberdeenshire]] |term_start2 = 28 February 1974 |term_end2 = 3 May 1979 |predecessor2 = [[Patrick Wolrige-Gordon]] |successor2 = [[Albert McQuarrie]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1935|7|16|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], Scotland |death_date = {{death date and age |df=yes|2006|9|15|1935|7|16}} |death_place = [[Edinburgh]], Scotland |party = [[Scottish National Party]] |spouse = Maureen Ferguson (m. 1960, div. 1982) |children = 4 |alma_mater = [[University of Edinburgh]] |occupation = [[Management consultant]] |religion = [[Church of Scotland]] }} '''Douglas Henderson''' (16 July 1935 – 15 September 2006) was a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[politician]]. He was [[Scottish National Party|Depute Leader of the Scottish National Party]] (SNP) from 1971 to 1973 and from 1979 to 1981. He served as a [[Scottish National Party]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[East Aberdeenshire (UK Parliament constituency)|East Aberdeenshire]] from 1974 to 1979, and held virtually every national office in the SNP, short of party leader. His political style has been described as "no-nonsense"{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/5353864.stm | title=Former deputy leader of SNP dies |work=[[BBC News]] |date=17 September 2006}} and "very blunt and forthright".{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/douglas-henderson-416599.html |title=Obituaries: Douglas Henderson. SNP MP and deputy leader |first=Tam |last=Dalyell |authorlink=Tam Dalyell |work=[[The Independent]] |date=19 September 2006 |accessdate=19 July 2015}} He was also known for his forceful public speaking, which former SNP leader [[Alex Salmond]] described as "messianic".{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12422437.Douglas_Henderson/ |title=Douglas Henderson |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=18 September 2006 |accessdate=19 July 2015}} ==Early life and career== Henderson was born in [[Edinburgh]], the son of a [[Porter (railroad)|railway porter]].{{cite news |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/obituaries/article2085416.ece |title=Douglas Henderson |work=[[The Times]] |date=19 September 2006 |accessdate=18 June 2016 |subscription=yes}} He won a [[scholarship]] to attend the [[Royal High School, Edinburgh|Royal High School]] and was then awarded a [[bursary]] which allowed him to attend the [[University of Edinburgh]] from 1952 to 1957. He graduated from Edinburgh with an [[Master of Arts (Scotland)|MA]] and an [[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]]. He worked as a [[management consultant]] in the UK and overseas. He married Maureen Ferguson in [[Johannesburg]] in 1960 and had four children, but they were later divorced. In later life, his home and business partner was English fashion designer Betty Davies; together, they founded [[Scottish Fashion International]]. In later years, he regularly attended [[St Giles Cathedral]], where his funeral was held on 7 October 2006. ==Political career== === Early career (1970–1983)=== Henderson became a supporter of [[Scottish independence]] at an early age, and joined the SNP aged 14.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/obituaries/douglas-henderson-1-1141217 |title=Douglas Henderson |work=The Scotsman |date=19 September 2006 |accessdate=18 June 2016}} He was President of the Edinburgh University Nationalist Club.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12421981.SNP_pays_tribute_as_veteran_nationalist_Douglas_Henderson_dies_at_71/ |title=SNP pays tribute as veteran nationalist Douglas Henderson dies at 71 |work=The Herald |date=18 September 2006 |accessdate=18 June 2016}} Henderson became heavily involved with the SNP after he returned to Scotland from South Africa in the mid-1960s.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/sep/26/guardianobituaries.obituaries1 |title=Obituary:Douglas Henderson. SNP chief whip happy to bring down Labour at any price |first=Brian |last=Wilson |authorlink=Brian Wilson (Labour politician) |work=[[The Guardian]] |date= 26 September 2006 |accessdate=19 July 2015}} He was also the director of programmes for [[Radio Free Scotland]]{{cite web|publisher=Gazetteer for Scotland |title =Douglas Henderson | url =http://www.scottish-places.info/people/famousfirst3201.html | accessdate = 24 December 2009 }} from 1963 to 1965, and was Senior vice-chairman (depute leader) of the SNP from 1970 to 1972,. He was selected as the SNP candidate for [[East Aberdeenshire (UK Parliament constituency)|East Aberdeenshire]] in 1972, and moved to live in the constituency, developing links with local fishermen, farmers and businessmen. He was elected at the [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974|February 1974 general election]], and re-elected in the [[United Kingdom general election, October 1974|October general election]] later that year. The SNP were in the ascendent, campaigning on the basis of "[[North sea oil|It's Scotland's oil]]". Henderson served as the [[whip (politics)|whip]] and was a leading member of the group of 11 SNP MPs in the House of Commons. In 1975, he negotiated a position for the SNP's [[Winnie Ewing]] in the British delegation to the [[European Parliament]], where she became known as "Madame Ecosse". He was later the SNP spokesman on employment and industry. He was instrumental in the SNP's decision to lay down a censure motion in the House of Commons, criticising the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government of [[James Callaghan]] after 1 March 1979 referendum vote on [[Scottish devolution]] failed to be approved by the required 40% of the electorate. At the time, the Labour government were reliant upon support from the SNP. The motion was carried by one vote on 28 March and Callaghan immediately called the general election which brought the Conservative Party led by [[Margaret Thatcher]] to power. Callaghan described the actions of the SNP as "[[turkeys voting for Christmas]]". Henderson lost his seat to Conservative [[Albert McQuarrie]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]] by less than 600 votes, and only two MPs from the SNP remained in the new Parliament. He returned to his business career, but with less success than the 1960s. At the SNP Conference in 1979, he was elected the party's Senior vice-chairman (now described as deputy leader) (to leader [[Gordon Wilson (Scottish politician)|Gordon Wilson]]), defeating [[Margo MacDonald]] for the post. He remained in this position until 1981, when he stood down on health grounds. He fought the new seat of [[Banff and Buchan (UK Parliament constituency)|Banff and Buchan]], which had largely replaced Aberdeenshire East in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 general election]], again losing to Albert McQuarrie by less than 1,000 votes. Future SNP leader [[Alex Salmond]] would represent this constituency from 1987, and it has since become a somewhat safe SNP seat with four-figure majorities over the [[Conservative and Unionist Party]]. He also suffered in his private life, being divorced in the early 1980s. ===Later revival (1998–2006)=== He was out of active politics for a long period as a result of misdiagnosed illness. He had a major operation in 1998 for cancer, and then several months of [[chemotherapy]], before he was able to resume his political duties for the SNP. He contested the [[European Parliament election, 2004 (United Kingdom)|2004 European Parliament election]] for the SNP but was not elected as he was placed fourth on the party's list and they gained only two seats. He also contested the [[Dumfries and Galloway (UK Parliament constituency)|Dumfries and Galloway]] seat at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]], finishing third behind [[Russell Brown (Scottish politician)|Russell Brown]], the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] candidate and [[Peter Duncan (British politician)|Peter Duncan]] the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] candidate.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/vote2005/html/684.stm |title=Election 2005. Result: Dumfries and Galloway |work=[[BBC News]] |date=6 May 2005}} In September 2005, following the retirement of [[Winnie Ewing]], he stood for the post of SNP President, polling 129 votes (30.00%) {{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} compared to 235 votes (54.65%) for [[Ian Hudghton]], [[Member of the European Parliament]], and 66 votes (15.35%) for onetime president [[William Wolfe]]. He was however successful in being elected as one of six ordinary members of the SNP's National Executive Committee. He was selected to fight the [[Falkirk East (Scottish Parliament constituency)|Falkirk East]] constituency for the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007]], and was ranked fourth on the SNP's [[Central Scotland (Scottish Parliament electoral region)|Central Scotland]] regional list. He died after a short illness in 2006, before the election could take place.[http://www.snp.org/news/snp_press_release.2006-09-16.6195726594 SNP pay tribute to Douglas Henderson]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, SNP press release, 16 September 2006. ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-douglas-henderson| Douglas Henderson }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{succession box | title = [[East Aberdeenshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Member for East Aberdeenshire]] | years = [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974|February 1974]] – [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979]] | before = [[Patrick Wolrige-Gordon]] | after = [[Albert McQuarrie]] }} {{s-ppo}} {{succession box|title=[[Scottish National Party]] Vice Chairman (Policy)|years=1968–1970|before=John Gair|after=[[Gordon Murray (politician)|Gordon Murray]]}} {{succession box|title=[[Scottish National Party|Senior vice-chairman (Depute Leader) of the Scottish National Party]]|years=1971–73|before=[[George Leslie (politician)|George Leslie]]|after=[[Gordon Wilson (Scottish politician)|Gordon Wilson]]}} {{succession box|title=[[Scottish National Party|Senior vice-chairman (Depute Leader) of the Scottish National Party]]|years=1979–81|before=[[Margo MacDonald]]|after=[[Jim Fairlie]]}} {{s-end}} {{Former SNP MPs}} {{SNP}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henderson, Douglas}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Politicians from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of the United Kingdom for Scottish constituencies]] [[Category:Politics of Aberdeenshire]] [[Category:People educated at the Royal High School, Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:Scottish National Party MPs]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:UK MPs 1974]] [[Category:UK MPs 1974–79]]

{{For|the Welsh rugby union international|Duncan Jones (rugby player)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Duncan Jones | image = Duncan Jones by Gage Skidmore 3.jpg | caption = Jones in July 2015 | birth_name = Duncan Zowie Haywood Jones | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|05|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bromley]], [[London]], England | occupation = {{flatlist| *Director *producer *screenwriter}} | alma_mater = {{ubl|[[College of Wooster]]|[[London Film School]]}} | years_active = 2002–present | spouse = {{marriage|Rodene Ronquillo|6 November 2012}} | children = 2 | parents = {{ubl|[[David Bowie]]|[[Angie Bowie]]}} }} '''Duncan Zowie Haywood Jones''' (born 30 May 1971) is an English film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is best known for directing the science fiction film ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'' (2009), for which he won the [[BAFTA Award for Outstanding Debut by a British Writer, Director or Producer]]. He has also directed ''[[Source Code]]'' (2011), ''[[Warcraft (film)|Warcraft]]'' (2016) and ''[[Mute (2018 film)|Mute]]'' (2018). ==Early life== Duncan Zowie Jones{{cite book | last = Buckley | first = David | title = Strange Fascination – David Bowie: The Definitive Story | edition = Revised & Updated | origyear = 1999 | year = 2005 | publisher = [[Virgin Publishing]] | location = London | isbn = 0-7535-1002-2 | page = 90 | quote = On 30 May 1971, Bowie's son, Duncan Zowie Jones, was born in Bromley Hospital.}} was born in [[Bromley]], London, on 30 May 1971, the only child of English singer-songwriter and musician [[David Bowie]] and his first wife, [[Angie Bowie|Angela "Angie" Bowie]] (''née'' Barnett), an American model and actress who was born and raised in [[Cyprus]].[http://www.angiebowie.net/Angies%20Bio.htm ANGIE BOWIE – BIOGRAPHY]. angiebowie.net{{cite web |url=http://www.angiebowie.net/Old%20Web%20Pages/cyprus.html |title=Cyprus: Land of Passion |last1=Bowie |first1=Angie |date=2000 |website=angiebowie.net |publisher=Angie Bowie |access-date=September 20, 2016 |quote=}} His mother also has [[Poles|Polish]] ancestry.Angela Bowie "Backstage Passes", pp. 29–30 His maternal grandfather, George, was a [[United States Army]] veteran and mining engineer who ran a mill for the [[Cyprus Mines Corporation]], while his maternal grandmother, Helena, was a naturalized [[Canadians|Canadian]]. His birth prompted his father to write the songs "[[Kooks (song)|Kooks]]" and "[[Oh! You Pretty Things]]" for his 1971 album ''[[Hunky Dory]]''.{{cite news |author=Graham, Caroline|title=Zowie Bowie: How a son of rock royalty survived a bitter rift with his mother to earn genuine success |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1205175/Zowie-Bowie-How-son-rock-royalty-survived-bitter-rift-mother-earn-genuine-success.html |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date= 8 August 2009|accessdate=6 October 2012 |location=London}} Mostly raised by his Scottish nanny, Marion Skene,{{cite news|author=Jones, Duncan|title= Marion Skene| url=https://twitter.com/manmademoon/status/845053720329019392?lang=en | date=23 March 2017 | accessdate=27 February 2018}} Jones spent time growing up in London, Berlin, and [[Vevey]]. He attended the first and second grade at the Commonwealth American School (now the International School of Lausanne) in [[Lausanne]]. When his parents divorced in February 1980, his father was granted custody of eight-year-old Jones (who was then known as "Zowie Bowie" to rhyme with his father's stage name) and he visited his mother on school holidays until ending contact with her at age 13.{{Cite web|url=http://wtfpod.libsyn.com/episode-892-duncan-jones-brendon-small|title=WTF with Marc Maron Podcast: Episode 892 - Duncan Jones / Brendon Small|website=wtfpod.libsyn.com|access-date=2018-02-22}} At age 14, he enrolled in the Scottish boarding school [[Gordonstoun]]. At the age of 12, he decided that he preferred to be called "Joey", and used this nickname until shortening it to "Joe" in his later teen years. The press reported that he went by "Joe" in 1992 when attending his father's wedding to fashion model [[Iman (model)|Iman]], where he was the best man.{{cite web|url=http://www.bowiewonderworld.com/press/press90.htm#Hello |title=David Bowie Wonderworld: Press Archives 90s |publisher=Bowiewonderworld.com |accessdate=2016-01-12}} He reverted to his birth name around the age of 18.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/07/movies/07itzk.html?scp=7&sq=angela%20bowie&st=cse | work=[[The New York Times]] | title=Son of Major Tom, at Ground Control | first=Dave | last=Itzkoff | date=7 June 2009 | accessdate=1 May 2010}} Jones is the half-brother of Alexandria "Lexi" Jones (born 2000), the daughter of his father and his father's second wife, Iman. He is also the half-brother of Stacia Larranna Celeste Lipka (born 1980) from his mother's relationship with musician Andrew Lipka, better known as Drew Blood. He has a stepsister, Zulekha Haywood (born 1978), who is the daughter of Iman and former [[NBA]] basketball player [[Spencer Haywood]], Iman's second husband. By 1995, Jones graduated with a bachelor's degree in philosophy from the [[College of Wooster]]. He then pursued a Ph.D degree at [[Vanderbilt University]] in Tennessee, but left before completion to attend [[London Film School]], where he then graduated as a director in 2001.[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/jul/19/observer-profile-duncan-jones-moon "Duncan Jones: Creating his own space odyssey".]. ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 14 January 2016 Whilst growing up, Jones dreamed of becoming a [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], and his father frequently praised what he called Jones' "natural strength".{{cite web|url=http://www.geni.com/people/Duncan-Jones/6000000009775328581 |title=Genealogy – Geni – private profile – Genealogy |publisher=[[Geni.com]] |accessdate=2016-01-12}} ==Career== [[File:Duncan Jones and David Bowie at the premiere of Moon.jpg|thumb|Jones with his father [[David Bowie]] at the premiere of ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'' in 2009]] Jones was one of many cameramen at his father's widely televised 50th birthday party directed by Englishman [[Tim Pope]] at [[Madison Square Garden]] in 1997 and also at two BowieNet concerts at [[Roseland Ballroom]] in New York City in June 2000. He was also the in-game cinematics director for the political simulator ''[[Republic: The Revolution]]'', as well as scripting elements of the game.{{cite web|last=Adams |first=Sam |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/duncan-jones,54252/ |title=Duncan Jones | Interview |publisher=[[The A.V. Club]] |date=2011-04-08 |accessdate=2013-05-20}} Jones directed the 2006 campaign for the [[French Connection (clothing)|French Connection]] fashion label. The concept of 'Fashion vs Style' was to re-invigorate the brand and move it away from the former incarnation of FCUK, which style pundits believed had become tired and overused.{{cite news | last = Akbar | first = Arifa | title = FCUK, off: fashion label decides to rest 'tired' logo | work = The Independent, UK | date = 16 August 2004 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/fcuk-off--fashion-label-decides-to-rest-tired-logo-556767.html| location=London}}{{cite news | last = Sweney | first = Mark | title = French Connection and Beattie part company | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 6 July 2006 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/jul/06/advertising| location=London}} The advert debuted in the week ending 20 February 2006 and featured two women (representing fashion and style) fighting and briefly kissing each other. The advertisement generated 127 complaints to the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]]. Jones's first feature film, ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'', was nominated for seven [[British Independent Film Awards 2009|British Independent Film Awards]] in 2009, and won two, Best British Independent Film, and the Douglas Hickox Award for Best British Director on their debut feature. It was also nominated for two [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Awards]] at the 2010 ceremony, winning Jones the [[BAFTA Award for Outstanding Debut by a British Writer, Director or Producer]]. The film has received 19 other nominations from film festivals and societies, including the BAFTA [[Carl Foreman]] Award. He directed the [[Summit Entertainment]] project ''[[Source Code]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34456/will-jake-gyllenhaal-crack-duncan-jones-source-code|title=Will Jake Gyllenhaal Crack Duncan Jones' ''Source Code''?|publisher=[[DreadCentral]]}} a science-fiction thriller from Vendome Pictures, which was produced by [[Mark Gordon]]. ''Source Code'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on 26{{nbsp}}July 2011 in the United States. Jones directed and co-wrote [[Warcraft (film)|''Warcraft'']], based on the [[Warcraft|video game series of the same name]], which was released in the summer of 2016.{{cite web|author=Borys Kit |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/warcraft-movie-lands-source-code-416956 |title='Warcraft' Movie Lands 'Source Code' Director (Exclusive) |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=2013-01-30 |accessdate=2016-01-12}} Jones next film would return to the science fiction genre and be called ''[[Mute (2017 film)|Mute]]'', starring [[Alexander Skarsgård]] and [[Paul Rudd]]. Jones had been developing the project for years and described it as a "spiritual sequel" to ''Moon'', and was inspired by [[Ridley Scott]]'s ''[[Blade Runner]]''.[http://www.empireonline.com/movies/news/exclusive-duncan-jones-talks-mute/ "Duncan Jones Talks Mute"]. Empire. Retrieved 14 January 2016 The film, set in [[Berlin]] forty years in the future, follows a mute bartender investigating his lover's disappearance.{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/11/paul-rudd-alexander-skarsgard-board-duncan-jones-mute-lotus-afm-ant-man-warcraft-moon-1201605098/ |title=Paul Rudd & Peter Skarsgard To Star In Duncan Jones' 'Mute' |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=2015-11-03 |accessdate=2015-11-04}} The film was produced and released by [[Netflix]], and became available to stream world-wide in February 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/title/80119233|title=Mute {{!}} Netflix Official Site|website=www.netflix.com|access-date=2018-03-15}} Through his social media, Jones announced his next project will be a [[Superhero film|superhero movie]], centered around the [[Rogue Trooper]], based on the [[2000 AD (comics)|2000 AD Comics]] character.https://screenrant.com/rogue-trooper-movie-director-duncan-jones/ ==Personal life== Jones announced his engagement to photographer Rodene Ronquillo on 28 June 2012. They married on 6 November 2012. On the same day, Ronquillo was diagnosed with [[breast cancer]]. The couple have been campaigning to raise awareness for the disease and for early diagnosis since then.{{cite web|url=http://www.fundraiseforbcrf.org/faf/donorReg/donorPledge.asp?ievent=1021963&supid=374586538 |title=Cancer Campaign Fundraising Page |publisher=Fundraiseforbcrf.org |date=2012-02-04 |accessdate=2013-05-20}}{{cite news|author=Sara Nathan |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2245851/David-Bowies-son-Duncan-Jones-weds-Rodene-Ronquillo-diagnosed-breast-cancer.html |title=Duncan Jones wedding |work=Daily Mail |date= 10 December 2012|accessdate=2013-05-20 |location=London}} On 10 July 2016, Ronquillo gave birth to their first child, a son.{{cite web|title=David Bowie's son announces late father was to become grandad|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/10/david-bowies-son-announces-late-father-was-to-become-grandad|website=theguardian.com|accessdate=11 February 2016}} On 1 October 2017, Jones announced that he and Ronquillo were expecting a second child.https://twitter.com/manmademoon/status/914612299427545088 Jones announced the birth of their daughter https://twitter.com/ManMadeMoon/status/990237327673909248 on 18 April 2018.https://twitter.com/ManMadeMoon/status/986543492976406528 ==Filmography== {| class = "wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! [[Film director|Director]] ! [[Screenwriter|Writer]] ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- |- | 2002 | ''Whistle'' | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | Short film |- | 2009 | ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'' | {{yes}} | {{yes|Story}} | [[BAFTA Award for Outstanding Debut by a British Writer, Director or Producer]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Ernest Solvay |image = Ernest Solvay 1900s.jpg |image_size = 240px |caption = Ernest Solvay (c. 1900) |birth_date = {{birth-date|16 April 1838|16 April 1838}} |birth_place = [[Rebecq]], [[Belgium]] |death_date = {{death-date and age|26 May 1922|16 April 1838}} |death_place = [[Ixelles]], Brussels, Belgium |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[Belgium|Belgian]] |ethnicity = |field = [[chemistry]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[ammonia-soda process]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }}
'''Ernest Gaston Joseph Solvay''' ({{IPA-fr|sɔlvɛ|lang}}; 16 April 1838 – 26 May 1922) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[chemist]], [[industrialist]] and [[philanthropist]].
Born at [[Rebecq]], he was prevented by acute [[pleurisy]] from going to university. He worked in his uncle's chemical factory from the age of 21.
In 1861, he developed the [[ammonia-soda process]] for the manufacturing of [[soda ash]] (anhydrous [[sodium carbonate]]) from brine (as a source of [[sodium chloride]]) and [[limestone]] (as a source of [[calcium carbonate]]). The process was an improvement over the earlier [[Leblanc process]].
He founded the company [[Solvay (company)|Solvay & Cie]] and established his first factory at [[Charleroi|Couillet]] (now merged into [[Charleroi]], [[Belgium]]) in 1863 and further perfected the process until 1872, when he patented it. Soon, [[Solvay process]] plants were established in the United Kingdom, the United States, Germany and Austria. Today, about 70 Solvay process plants are still operational worldwide.
The exploitation of his [[patent]]s brought Solvay considerable wealth, which he used for [[philanthropic]] purposes, including the establishment in 1894 of the "Institut des Sciences Sociales" (ISS) or Institute for Sociology at the [[Free University of Brussels]] (now split into the [[Université Libre de Bruxelles]] and the [[Vrije Universiteit Brussel]]), as well as [[Solvay Conference|International Institutes for Physics and Chemistry]]. In 1903, he founded the [[Solvay Business School]] which is also part of the [[Free University of Brussels]]. In 1911, he began a series of important conferences in physics, known as the [[Solvay Conference]]s, whose participants included luminaries such as [[Max Planck]], [[Ernest Rutherford]], [[Maria Skłodowska-Curie]], [[Henri Poincaré]], and (then only 32 years old) [[Albert Einstein]]. A later conference would include [[Niels Bohr]], [[Werner Heisenberg]], [[Max Born]], and [[Erwin Schrödinger]].
He was twice elected to the [[Belgian Senate]] for the [[Liberal Party (Belgium)|Liberal Party]] and granted honorary title of [[Minister of State (Belgium)|Minister of State]] at the end of his life. [[Solvay, New York]] and [[Rosignano Solvay]], the locations of the first Solvay process plants in the United States and in Italy, are also named after him.
Solvay died at [[Ixelles]] at the age of 84 and is interred there in the [[Ixelles Cemetery]]. [[Image:1911 Solvay conference.jpg|300px|thumb|The portrait of participants to the first [[Solvay Conference]] in 1911. Ernest Solvay is the third seated from the left. Solvay was not present at the time the photo was taken, so his photo was cut and pasted onto this one for the official release]]
== Honours == * '''1918''' : [[Minister of State (Belgium)|Minister of State]], By Royal Decree.<ref>21 november 1918</ref> * '''1918''' : Grand Cordon in the [[Order of Leopold (Belgium)|Order of Leopold]], by Royal Decree.<ref>RD 8.12.1918</ref>
==See also== *[[Solvay Institute of Sociology]] *[[Emile Waxweiler]] *[[Solvay Hut]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * Bertrand, Louis, ''Ernest Solvay. Een hervormer op maatschappelijk gebied'', Brussels, Agence Dechenne, 1918, 113 p. * Boianovsky, Mauro, Erreygers, Guido, ''Social comptabilism and pure credit systems. Solvay and [[Knut Wicksell|Wicksell]] on monetary reform'', in : Fontaine, Philippe, Leonard, Robert, (ed.), The experiment in the history of economics, London, Routledge, 2005, pp. 98–134. * Despy-Meyer, Andrée, Devriese Didier (ed.), ''Ernest Solvay et son temps'', Brussels, Archives de l'ULB, 1997, 349 p. * Erreygers, Guido, ''The economic theories and social reform proposals of Ernest Solvay (1838–1922)'', in : Samuels, Warren J. (red.), European economists of the early 20th century, volume 1. Studies of neglected thinkers of Belgium, France, The Netherlands and Scandinavia, Cheltenham-Northampton, Edward Elgar, 1998, pp. 221–262. * Rapaille, Maxime, Solvay, un géant. ''Des rives de la Sambre aux confins de la terre'', Bruxelles, Didier Hatier, 1989, 187 p. * Author not stated. "Vie D'Ernest Solvay" Bruxelles, Chez le Libraire Lamertin, 1929, 164 pp. Ten heliogravures (two in color) Soft cover. Notation at front reads "Les principaux travaux d'Ernest Solvay, sur des questions scientifiques, politiques et sociales, paraitront en deux volumes, de meme format que celui-ci, chez Lamertin, fin 1929, sous le titre : Notes, Lettres et Discours d'Ernest Solvay."
==External links== * {{Commonscatinline}} * {{Wikiquote-inline}}
{{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}}

revision.text:
{{Competition law}} {{More footnotes|date=August 2009}} The '''essential facilities doctrine''' (sometimes also referred to as the '''essential facility doctrine''') is a [[legal doctrine]] which describes a particular type of claim of [[monopolization]] made under [[competition law]]s. In general, it refers to a type of [[anti-competitive behavior]] in which a firm with [[market power]] uses a "[[Bottleneck (logistics)|bottleneck]]" in a market to deny competitors entry into the market. It is closely related to a claim for [[refusal to deal]].
The doctrine has its origins in [[United States law]], but it has been adopted (often with some modification) into the legal systems of [[Law of the United Kingdom|the United Kingdom]], [[Law of Australia|Australia]], [[Law of South Africa|South Africa]], and the [[Law of the European Union|European Union]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
==Overview== Under the essential facilities doctrine, a [[monopoly|monopolist]] found to own "a facility essential to other competitors" is required to provide reasonable use of that facility, unless some aspect of it precludes shared access.<ref>Abbott B. Lipsky, Jr. & J. Gregory Sidak, [https://www.criterioneconomics.com/docs/essential_facilities1.pdf ''Essential Facilities''], 51 {{smallcaps|Stan. L. Rev.}} 1187, 1190–91 (1999).</ref> The basic elements of a [[Claim (legal)|legal claim]] under this doctrine under [[United States antitrust law]], which a [[plaintiff]] is required to show to establish liability, are:
#control of the essential facility by a monopolist #a competitor’s inability to practically or reasonably duplicate the essential facility #the denial of the use of the facility to a competitor; and #the feasibility of providing the facility to competitors
The [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]]'s ruling in ''[[Verizon Communications v. Law Offices of Curtis V. Trinko, LLP|Verizon v. Trinko]]'', 540 U.S. 398 (2004), in effect added a fifth element: absence of regulatory oversight from an agency (the [[Federal Communications Commission]], in that case) with power to compel access.
These elements are difficult for potential plaintiffs to establish for several reasons. It is quite difficult for a plaintiff to demonstrate that a particular facility is "essential" to entry into and/or competition within the [[relevant market]]. The plaintiff must demonstrate that the "facility" must be something so indispensable to entry or competition that it would be impossible for smaller firms to compete with the market leader. Likewise, the plaintiff must show that compelling the [[Dominance (economics)|dominant firm]] to permit others to use the facility would not interfere with the ability of the dominant firm to serve its own customers.
==Development== The first notable case to address the anti-competitive implications of an essential facility was the Supreme Court's judgment in ''[[United States v. Terminal Railroad Association]]'', 224 U.S. 383 (1912).<ref>Abbott B. Lipsky, Jr. & J. Gregory Sidak, [https://www.criterioneconomics.com/docs/essential_facilities1.pdf ''Essential Facilities''], 51 Stan. L. Rev.]] 1187, 1189–91 (1999).</ref> A group of railroads controlling all railway bridges and switching yards into and out of [[St. Louis]] prevented competing railway companies from offering transportation to and through that destination. The court held it to be an illegal restraint of trade.<ref>224 U.S. 383 (1912), at 409-10</ref>
Similar decisions include, * ''[[Associated Press v. United States]]'', 326 U.S. 1 (1945), in which the Supreme Court found that the [[Associated Press]] bylaws which limited membership and therefore access to copyrighted news services violated the Sherman Act. * In ''[[Lorain Journal Co. v. United States]]'', 342 U.S. 143, 146-49 (1951), ''[[The Lorain Journal]]'' was the only local business doing news and advertisements in town. The case was that refusing to place an ad for the customers of a small radio station was a Sherman Act violation. In the end, the court accepted an offer to simply accept the advertisements. * ''[[Otter Tail Power Co. v. United States]]'', 410 U.S. 366, 377-79 (1973), in which the Supreme Court found that [[Otter Tail Corporation|Otter Tail]], an electrical utility which sold electricity at both directly to consumers and to municipalities who resold to consumers, violated the Sherman Act by refusing to supply electricity at wholesale, instead serving customers directly itself. * ''[[Aspen Skiing Co. v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corp.]]'', 427 U.S. 585 (1985), upholding the ''Lorain Journal'' decision in holding that Aspen Skiing violated § 2 of the [[Sherman Act]] by refusing to honor vouchers and [[ski lift]] tickets after it had previously done so. * ''[[Otter Tail Power Co. v. United States#Hecht case|Hecht v. Pro Football]]'' where potential American Football League franchise did not show they needed Washington's [[RFK Stadium]], the essential facilities doctrine was not met.
==Application of the doctrine== There is controversy about what exactly constitutes an "essential facility". While the doctrine has most frequently been applied to [[Natural monopoly|natural monopolies]] such as [[Public utility|utilities]] and owners of transportation facilities, it has also been applied{{Specify|date=May 2012}} in situations involving [[intellectual property]]. For example, it is possible for a court to apply the doctrine in a case where one competitor refuses to sell materials protected by [[copyright]] or [[patent]] to potential competitors.
==See also== * [[Competition law]] * [[Essential patent]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== Sullivan, E. Thomas, and [[Herbert Hovenkamp|Hovenkamp, Herbert]]. ''Antitrust Law, Policy, and Procedure: Cases, Materials, and Problems, Fifth Edition''. [[LexisNexis]] Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|0-8205-6104-5}} pp. 701–706.
==External links== * [[Robert Pitofsky]], [http://scholarship.law.georgetown.edu/facpub/346 ''The Essential Facilities Doctrine Under United States Antitrust Law''], 70 {{smallcaps|Antitrust}} L.J. 443 (2002). * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080304023910/http://www.ictregulationtoolkit.org/en/PracticeNote.aspx?id=2517 Brief explanation of the doctrine] from the [[International Telecommunication Union]] {{Dead link|date=November 2015}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928121440/http://www.compcom.co.za/resources/september2002/pages/04_facilities.htm Article on the doctrine] from the [[Competition Commission of South Africa]] {{Dead link|date=November 2015}}
[[Category:Competition law]] [[Category:United States antitrust law]] [[Category:Legal doctrines and principles]]

revision.text:
'''Francesco Carlà''' is an Italian journalist, professor, investor and entrepreneur.
Among the various activities in the financial field, he is known to the public to be the founder and CEO of the software house [[Simulmondo]], the videogame leader in Italy at the turn of the 80s and 90s.
== Biography == His career started in 1983, when he began working for television and radio broadcasts, including [[Mediaset]] and [[RAI|Rai]], as an expert in computer tecnhologies and softwares.
He conduct the TV program "Videogames Weekend" for [[Rai 2]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iulm.it/Default.aspx?idPage=2916&id_docente=187|title=iulm page|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
After graduating with the first thesis on videogames history in the world,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305225624/http://www.tils.com/open_mind/asterisco/Technowlogy/Technowlogy_2-2_2.asp|title=TILS|date=2007-03-05|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref> he began to work in the videogame field. Initially he wrote for several years on a column on MCmicrocomputer magazine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/adpware/docs/mc047/045|title=047 MCmicrocomputer|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-04-07|language=en}}</ref> Subsequently, in 1987, he founded [[Simulmondo]], one of the very first videogame software houses in Italy.
In the following years, he will also be known for being a producer of several videogames, including "Bocce", knows as the first Italian videogame and some series of graphic adventures starring [[Diabolik]], [[Dylan Dog]], [[Tex Willer|Tex]] and [[Spider-Man|Spiderman]].
Overall, the company will produce about 150 videogames in just over 10 years.
In 1995 he began to take an interest in online finance, creating a free financial newsletter. Noting the interest from the financial newsletter members, in 1999 he founded FinanzaWorld.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.finanzaworld.it/statico/page/4/partner|title=FinanzaWorld: Partner|website=www.finanzaworld.it|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref>
Since 2000 he has published several books, mainly in the economic-financial field,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/blog/fcarla/|title=Francesco Carlà, Il Fatto Quotidiano|website=Il Fatto Quotidiano|language=it-IT|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref> and since 2005 he has been dealing with some columns, this time in newspapers such as [[Panorama (magazine)|Panorama]] and [[L'espresso|L'Espresso]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080113183843/http://www.fortunecity.de/boerse/euro/95/arnm9946.html|title=Investire online di Francesco Carlà|date=2008-01-13|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref>
For three years he was among the authors and the host of Netstocks, on the satellite channel [[Rai News24|RaiNews24]], a television column dedicated to the New Economy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apogeonline.com/libri/88-7303-910-3/scheda|title=Trading online II edizione {{!}} Apogeonline|website=www.apogeonline.com|language=it|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref>
He also edited the Soldi e felicità (Money and Happiness) section for the Italian edition of Vanity Fair.
He was a professor in Theories and Techniques of New Media, eCulture and Financial Communication at the [[IULM University of Milan|IULM University]] until 2008 <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070919060634/http://it.biz.yahoo.com/finanzaworld/guida10.html|title=Profilo di Francesco Carlà|last=|first=|date=2007-09-19|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-07}}</ref> and he was professor of Communication Systems and Technologies at [[Sapienza University of Rome|Sapienza University]] in Rome from 1996 to 2002.
== Video games == The list can be consulted in the following page, [[Simulmondo#List of games|Simulmondo titles]], in every title he the director/producer, and in many games like ''I Play: 3D Soccer'', ''Simulman'' and ''SoccerChamp'' he was also the creator.
== Books ==
* ''Space Invaders. La vera storia dei videogames'', Interaction libri, 1993 ** ''Space Invaders. La vera storia dei videogames'', seconda edizione, Castelvecchi Edizioni, 1996 * ''Trading online. La guida. I principi della finanza democratica. Dal Nasdaq al nuovo mercato'', Apogeo, 2000 * ''Simulmondo'', Apogeo, 2001 * ''Italia-google. Alla ricerca dell'innovazione digitale'', Edizioni FAG, 2006 * ''La Finanza Democratica. La guida completa per diventare investitori intelligenti'', Edizioni Sonda, 2009
== See also ==
* [[Simulmondo]]
== References == <references />
== Bibliography ==
* AA.VV., ''Annuario dei giornalisti italiani 2012'', Ordine dei Giornalisti, 2012, p. 686.
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Carla, Francesco}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Italian journalists]] [[Category:Italian male journalists]] [[Category:Italian company founders]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Fred Anton Maier}} {{Infobox person |name = Frederick Anton III |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1934}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |death_date = November 1 or 2, 2017 |death_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |alma_mater = [[Villanova University School of Law]] |spouse = |known_for = |occupation = |nationality = }} '''Frederick Anton III''' was President and CEO of the [[Pennsylvania]] Manufacturers Association and the [[Pennsylvania]] Manufacturers Insurance Company.
A native of [[Philadelphia]], Pennsylvania, he graduated from [[Villanova University School of Law]] in 1958 and practiced law in Philadelphia.<ref name=pcnprofile>{{cite video|people = Bill Bova and Fred Anton|date = 2007|title = PCN Profiles: Fred Anton|url= http://www.pamanufacturers.org/pages/index.php?pID=1301|format = Television interview|publisher = [[Pennsylvania Cable Network]]}}</ref> In 1962, he took a job as a claims attorney with the Pennsylvania Manufactures Insurance Company, where he handled [[workers compensation]] cases.<ref name=pcnprofile /> He became president of the Pennsylvania Manufactures Insurance Company in 1972 and became president of the Pennsylvania Manufactures Association in 1975.<ref name=pcnprofile />
As a Republican, he was a delegate to the [[1992 Republican National Convention|1992]], [[1996 Republican National Convention|1996]], [[2000 Republican National Convention|2000]], [[2004 Republican National Convention|2004]] and [[2008 Republican National Convention|2008]] [[Republican National Convention]]s.<ref name=pgbio>{{cite web| last = Kestenbaum| first = Lawrence | authorlink = Lawrence Kestenbaum| title = Index to Politicians: Antilla to Aoelua | work = [[The Political Graveyard]]| publisher = | date = March 24, 2009| url = http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/antilla-anzelowitz.html#0M300JCVD| accessdate = 2009-09-12}}</ref>
The ''[[Pennsylvania Report]]'' named him to the 2003 "The Pennsylvania Report Power 75" list of influential figures in [[Pennsylvania politics]], calling him "an important financial player for GOP" ([[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]])<ref name=pareport2003>{{cite web| title = The PA Report "Power 75" List| work = [[Pennsylvania Report]]| publisher = Capital Growth, Inc.| date = January 31, 2003| url = http://www.pa-report.com/uploaded_pdf/PAReportPower75_.pdf| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060920200116/http://www.pa-report.com/uploaded_pdf/PAReportPower75_.pdf| archivedate = 2006-09-20| format = PDF| deadurl = yes| df = }}</ref> In 2009, the ''[[Pennsylvania Report]]'' named him to "The Pennsylvania Report 100" list of influential figures in Pennsylvania politics and noted that he remains a "key figure in the business community" and "[t]he "godfather" of all conservative organizations in the state."<ref name=pareport>{{cite web| title = PA Report 100| work = [[Pennsylvania Report]]| publisher = Capital Growth, Inc.| date = January 23, 2009| url = http://www.pa-report.com/uploaded_pdf/PA%20Report%20100%20-%20Jan%2023,%202009.pdf| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5j0zKOG5a?url=http://www.pa-report.com/uploaded_pdf/PA%20Report%20100%20-%20Jan%2023%2C%202009.pdf| archivedate = 2009-08-14| format = PDF| deadurl = yes| df = }}</ref> He was named to the [[PoliticsPA]] list of "Sy Snyder's Power 50" list of influential individuals in [[Pennsylvania politics]] in 2002.<ref name=power>{{cite web | title = Sy Snyder's Power 50 | work = [[PoliticsPA]] | publisher = The Publius Group | year = 2002 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20020421165540/http://www.politicspa.com/features/power50.htm | url = http://www.politicspa.com/features/power50.htm | archivedate = 2002-04-21 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> In 2010, he was named of the "Top 10 Republicans" in Pennsylvania by ''Politics Magazine,'' who noted that he "funds much of the conservative infrastructure in the state, such as the right of-center think-tank [[Commonwealth Foundation for Public Policy Alternatives|Commonwealth Foundation]]."<ref>{{Cite news| last = Roarty| first = Alex| author2 = Sean Coit| title = Pennsylvania Influencers| newspaper = Politics Magazine| pages = 44–49| publisher = | date = January 2010| url = http://politicsmagazine.com/uploads/Image/Politics_PA_influencers_web.pdf| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5nNQI9Qgt?url=http://politicsmagazine.com/uploads/Image/Politics_PA_influencers_web.pdf| archivedate = 2010-02-08| deadurl = yes| df = }}</ref>
==Death==
Anton was found dead in the Delaware River, near his residence, on November 2, 2017 <ref>http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/fred-anton-gop-powerbroker-found-dead-in-delaware-river-20171102.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Use "free and open-source" instead of "free and open source" (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{other uses|Free license (disambiguation)}} {{Expand Russian|Свободная лицензия|date=June 2012}} A '''free license''' or '''open license'''<ref name="opendefinition"/><ref>[http://opensource.org/docs/osd ''The Open Source Definition'']</ref> is a [[license agreement]] which contains conditions permitted to the user from the holder on a specific list of uses for his work, which gives him [[Four Freedoms (Free software)|four major freedoms]].
Without a special license, these uses are normally prohibited by the laws of [[copyright]].
Most free licenses are worldwide, [[royalty-free]], [[Non-exclusive license|non-exclusive]], and perpetual (see [[List of copyright durations|copyright durations]]).
Free licenses are often the basis of [[crowdsourcing]] and [[crowdfunding]] projects.
The invention of the term "free license" and the focus on the [[rights of users]] were connected to the sharing traditions of the [[hacker culture]] of the 1970s public domain software ecosystem, the social and political [[free software movement]] (since 1980) and the [[Open source movement]] (since the 1990s).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twobits.net/pub/Kelty-TwoBits.pdf |title=The Cultural Significance of free Software - Two Bits |first=Christpher M. |last=Kelty |publisher=[[Duke University]] press - durham and london |year=2008 |pages=99 |quote=''Prior to 1998, Free Software referred either to the Free Software Foundation (and the watchful, micromanaging eye of Stallman) or to one of thousands of different commercial, avocational, or university-research projects, processes, licenses, and ideologies that had a variety of names: sourceware, freeware, shareware, open software, public domain software, and so on. The term Open Source, by contrast, sought to encompass them all in one movement.''}}</ref>
These rights were codified by different groups and organizations for different domains in [[Free Software Definition]], [[Open Source Definition]], [[Debian Free Software Guidelines]], [[Definition of Free Cultural Works]] and the [[The Open Definition|Open definition]].<ref name="opendefinition">[http://opendefinition.org/od/2.1/en/ Open Definition 2.1] on opendefinition.org ''"This essential meaning matches that of “open” with respect to software as in the Open Source Definition and is synonymous with “free” or “libre” as in the Free Software Definition and Definition of Free Cultural Works."''</ref> These definitions were then transformed into licenses, using the [[copyright]] as legal mechanism. Since then, ideas of free/open licenses spread into different spheres of society.
[[Open source movement|Open source]], [[free culture movement|free culture]] (unified as [[Free and open-source software|Free and open-source movement]]), [[anticopyright]], [[Wikimedia Foundation]] projects, [[Public Domain]] advocacy groups and [[pirate parties]] are connected with free and open licenses.
== Philosophy == {{main|Free software movement#Philosophy|Free culture movement}}
== Classification and licenses == [[File:License network by bokanko.jpg|300px|thumb|Network of licenses (and years of license creation).]]
=== By freedom === * Agreement, which is related to the [[public domain]] ** [[CC0|Creative Commons CC0]] ** [[WTFPL]] ** [[Unlicense]] ** Public Domain Dedication and License (PDDL)<ref>[http://opendatacommons.org/licenses/pddl/1-0/ PDDL 1.0] on opendatacommons.org</ref> * [[Permissive license]]s ** [[BSD License]] ** [[MIT License]] ** [[Mozilla Public License]] (file-based permissive copyleft) ** [[Creative Commons Attribution]] * [[Copyleft license]]s ** [[GNU GPL]], [[GNU LGPL|LGPL]] (weaker copyleft), [[GNU AGPL|AGPL]] (stronger copyleft) ** [[Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike]] ** [[Mozilla Public License]] ** [[Common Development and Distribution License]] ** [[GFDL]] (without invariant sections) ** [[Free Art License]]
=== By type of content === * [[Free software licence]]s ** [[The Free Software Definition]] * [[Open Content]] ** [[Open Content License]] ** [[Open Publication License]] * [[Free content]] licenses ** [[Definition of Free Cultural Works]] * [[Open-source hardware]] licenses * [[Database]] licenses ([[Creative Commons]] v4 and [[Open Database Licence]]) * [[Open patent]] licenses
=== By authors === * [[Free Software Foundation]] * [[Open Source Initiative]] * [[Creative Commons]] * [[Microsoft]] ** [[Microsoft Public License]] ** [[Microsoft Reciprocal License]] * [[Open Content Project]] * [[Open Data Commons]] from [[Open Knowledge Foundation]] ** [[Public Domain Dedication and License]] (PDDL) ** [[Attribution License]] (ODC-By) ** [[Open Database License]] (ODC-ODbL
== Problems == * [[License compatibility]] * [[License proliferation]] * [[Permissive free software license|Permissive]] vs. [[copyleft]]
== By countries == [[Creative Commons]] has affiliates in more than 100 jurisdictions all over the world.
=== USA ===
=== European Union === [[EUPL]] was created in the [[European Union]].
==== Germany ==== [[Harald Welte]] created [[gpl-violations.org]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.en.html Various Licenses and Comments about Them - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation] * [http://www.debian.org/legal/licenses/ License information - Debian] * [http://opensource.org/licenses/ Open Source Licenses] * [http://freedomdefined.org/Licenses Licenses - Definition of Free Cultural Works] * [http://freedomdefined.org/OSHW proposed Open Source Hardware (OSHW) Statement of Principles and Definition v1.0]
{{FOSS}} {{Intellectual property activism}} {{Software distribution}} {{Creative Commons topics}}

revision.text:
'''Harry Anson Finney''' (November 19, 1886 – May 8, 1966) was an American accountant, and Professor of accounting at the [[Northwestern University]]. He is known as prolific author in the field of [[accounting]].<ref name="BC 1976">{{cite journal |last1=Burns |first1=Thomas J.| author-link1= Thomas J. Burns |last2=Coffman |first2=Edward N. | author-link2= Edward N. Coffman|title=The Accounting Hall of Fame: A Profile of the Members|journal=[[Journal of Accounting Research]] |volume=14 |issue= 2 |pages=342–347 |jstor=2490547|date= 1976 |registration=yes }}</ref> who had written a leading textbook in accounting, entitled "Principles of accounting" (1935).<ref name="RMK 2014">[[M. Chatfield]] & [[R. Vangermeersch]] (eds.) ''[http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/cdm/ref/collection/aah/id/350 History of Accounting: An International Encyclopedia: An International Encyclopedia].'' (2014). p. 265</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Postville, Iowa]] to Solon B. and Ellen Bike Finney, Finney obtained his BA in economics in 1913 at the [[University of Chicago]]. In 1917 he obtained his CPA license for the state of Illinois.<ref name="AH0F 2015">{{cite web|url=http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/harry-anson-finney/ |title=Harry Anson Finney|publisher=[[The Accounting Hall of Fame]] |accessdate=2015-02-13}}</ref>
After graduation Finney taught economics at a high school, and later at the Walton School of Commerce in Chicago. In 1920 he moved to the [[Northwestern University]], where he was Professor of accounting until his retirement in 1944. Over the years he also worked as accountant. In 1923 he had joined the Haskins & Sells accountancy firm, and later founded Baumann, Finney & Company.<ref name="AH0F 2015"/>
Finney was editor for the ''[[Journal of Accountancy]]'' from 1920 to 1928, and was elected President of the Illinois Society of CPAs for the year 1928-29. Finney authored and co-authored a series of successful textbooks on accounting, from which he sold in total more than two million copies.<ref name="AH0F 2015"/>
== Selected publications == * Finney, Harry Anson and Joseph Clifton Brown. ''Modern Business Arithmetic,'' (1916) * Finney, Harry Anson. "Introduction To Actuarial Science." American Institute of Accountants. (1920) * Finney, Harry Anson. ''Consolidated statements for holding company and subsidiaries.'' Prentice-Hall, Incorporated. (1922). * Finney, Harry Anson. ''Principles of accounting.'' (1935). * Finney, H. A., Miller, H. E., Gentry, J. A., & Johnson, G. L. ''Principles of accounting: advanced'' (Vol. 2). Prentice-Hall. (1965). * Finney, Harry Anson, and Herbert E. Miller. ''Answers to Questions and Solutions to Problems in Principles of Accounting: Intermediate.'' Prentice-Hall. (1965). * Finney, H. A., Miller, H. E., Johnson, G. L., & Gentry, J. A. ''Principles of accounting.'' Prentice Hall. (1970).
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/harry-anson-finney/ Harry Anson Finney], The Accounting Hall of Fame
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | image = Håkan Buskhe in Brazil 2010 001.jpg | image_size = 200px | name = Håkan Buskhe | caption = | birth_name = Kurt Ove Håkan Buskhe | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|11|8|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Örnsköldsvik]], [[Sweden]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Swedish | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = [[Chalmers University of Technology]] | occupation = President and CEO, [[Saab Group|Saab]] | known for = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relatives = | website = }}
'''Kurt Ove ''Håkan'' Buskhe''' (born 8 November 1963 in [[Örnsköldsvik]]) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] businessman, better known as the president and CEO of the Swedish aerospace and defence company [[Saab Group]], a role he has been in since September 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=4 krav avgjorde Saabs val av vd |url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/4-krav-avgjorde-saabs-val-av-vd_4621635.svd|website=SvD.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Han blir ny Saabchef|url=http://www.privataaffarer.se/borsguiden/han-blir-ny-saabchef-1-104481|website=PivataAffärer.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Håkan Buskhe|url=http://www.di.se/amnen/buskhe-hakan/|website=di.se|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923214253/http://www.di.se/amnen/buskhe-hakan/|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}}</ref>
In addition to this role, he is also the chairman of the board of directors of Sweden’s [[state-owned]] logistics and transport company [[Green Cargo]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Hollander, Mats|title=Håkan Buskhe ny ordförande i Green Cargos styrelse |url=http://www.greencargo.com/sv/Pressrum/Nyheter/Nyhetsarkiv/Hakan-Buskhe-ny-ordforande-i-Green-Cargos-styrelse/ |website=Green Cargo}}</ref>
==Early life== Buskhe was born in 1963 in the north-east of Sweden, in Örnsköldsvik. He attended [[Chalmers University of Technology]], where he earned a [[Master of Science]] degree in science and engineering, as well as a [[Licentiate (degree)|licentiate]] in engineering, and a [[diploma]] in corporate management.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
==Career== He began his career in the military, carrying out military service during the 1980s, where he worked as a weapons technician. This gave him a basic initiation into the world of arms and defence, the only such experience he would later take into his role at Saab. His first real career move was at a logistics company called Scansped where he joined in 1988 as assistant to the [[managing director]]. He rose through the ranks of this company and became head of EDP in 1990, where he was responsible for the implementation of a transport administration IT system across [[Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
In 1994, he moved to [[Carlsberg Group|Carlsberg]], serving in various key senior logistics roles before he moved on to the electrical wholesale company Storel in 1998, where he eventually became managing director.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref> In 2002, he became the CEO of logistics firm Schenker North, where he later became a board member in 2005.
In 2006, Bushke joined the [[Germany|German]] energy company [[E.ON]]’s Swedish division, E.ON Sverige, where he served as senior vice president before being appointed as president and CEO of the entire [[Nordic region]]. It was his successful time here that made his reputation as future candidate for Saab’s leadership.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
In September 2010, Bushke was appointed as CEO of [[Saab Group]], with the chairman [[Marcus Wallenberg (born 1956)|Marcus Wallenberg]] choosing him for his breadth of expertise and focus on the high-tech field.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Bushke is married with three daughters. <ref>{{cite web|title=SWEDEN IS A MODEL: INTERVIEW WITH HÅKAN BUSKHE - THE CEO OF SAAB|url=http://saab.com/pt/air/gripen-fighter-system/gripen/gripen.com/Orgulho-de-ser-Brasileiro/Updates-news/filtered-stories/sweden-is-a-model/|website=Saab|date=26 February 2014}}</ref> The oldest daughter Katrine (b. 1988)<ref>{{citation|title=Sveriges befolkning 1990|year=2011|publisher=Svensk arkivinformation (SVAR), Riksarkivet|language=sv|isbn=978-91-88366-91-7}}</ref> lives in Gothenburg.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Buskhe, Hakan}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:People from Örnsköldsvik Municipality]] [[Category:Chalmers University of Technology alumni]]
