revision.text:
{{Infobox street | name = Jalan Jenderal Sudirman | marker_image = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alternate_name = | image = JalanJenderalSudirmanJakarta.jpg | image_size = | image_map = | caption = A view of Jalan Jenderal Sudirman | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_alt = | other_name = Sudirman Road | former_names = Djalan Raja Djendral Sudirman | part_of = | namesake = | type = | owner = Pemprov DKI Jakarta | maint = Dinas Pekerjaan Umum DKI Jakarta | length_km = 4.1 | length_ref = | length_notes = | width = | area = | addresses = | location = [[South Jakarta]] and [[Central Jakarta]] | arrondissement = | quarter = | postal_code = | metro = | coordinates = | direction_a = South | terminus_a = [[Patung Pemuda Membangun]] | direction_b = North | terminus_b = The bridge of [[Jakarta Flood Canal|West Flood Canal]] | junction = | north = | east = | south = | west = | main_contractor = | cost = | references = | commissioning_date = | construction_start_date = | completion_date = | inauguration_date = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | demolition_date = | designer = | known_for = | status = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''Jalan Jenderal Sudirman''' or ''' Jalan Sudirman''' ('''Sudirman Road''') is a major thoroughfare in [[Jakarta]] in [[Indonesia]]. The road runs from [[Patung Pemuda Membangun]] at the south end to the bridge of the [[Jakarta Flood Canal|West Flood Canal]] at the north. The road had been built between 1949 and 1953 to connect Central Jakarta with [[Kebayoran Baru]].{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=37}} The historically-prominent road is located in one of Jakarta's central business district area, marking the western side of [[Golden Triangle of Jakarta|Jakarta Golden Triangle]] and the eastern side of [[Jakarta Platinum Triangle]].
==Description== Sudirman is one of Jakarta's most prominent main roads because of its location in the city's central business district. Sudirman Road was constructed in the late 1940s and was the foundation of the modern image of Jakarta. The road was named after a [[National Hero of Indonesia|National Hero]] [[Sudirman]], whose statue was erected near the north end of the road in September 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ariesaksono.wordpress.com/2008/05/28/patung-jenderal-sudirman-jakarta/ |title=Patung Jenderal Sudirman-Jakarta |author=Arue Saksono |date=May 28, 2008 |website=Arie Saksono - Saya Orang Indonesia |publisher=Wordpress |access-date=November 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109112030/https://ariesaksono.wordpress.com/2008/05/28/patung-jenderal-sudirman-jakarta/ |archive-date=November 9, 2016 |dead-url=no |quote= |df= }}</ref> The entire length of Sudirman Road marks the boundary of [[Central Jakarta]] (north of the road) and [[South Jakarta]] (south of the road).
Sudirman Road suffers from Jakarta's heavy traffic congestion. In June 2016, an [[Road space rationing|odd-even traffic scheme]] was implemented on Sudirman, replacing the [[High-occupancy vehicle lane|"Three-in-One"]] scheme which was introduced on December 23, 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.merdeka.com/jakarta/sejarah-pemberlakuan-3-in-1-di-jakarta.html |title=Sejarah Pemberlakuan 3-in-1 di Jakarta |author= |date=March 29, 2016 |website=Merdeka.com |publisher=KLN Kapanlagi Network |access-date=November 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109112934/https://www.merdeka.com/jakarta/sejarah-pemberlakuan-3-in-1-di-jakarta.html |archive-date=November 9, 2016 |dead-url=no |quote= |df= }}</ref> The replacement was deemed necessary in order to eliminate the informal profession of [[car jockey]]s, which caused more problems than solutions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/04/end-of-the-road-jakartas-passengers-for-hire-targeted-by-carpooling-crackdown |title=End of the road: Jakarta's 'passengers for hire' targeted by carpooling crackdown |author= |date=November 9, 2016 |website=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |access-date=November 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109113400/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/04/end-of-the-road-jakartas-passengers-for-hire-targeted-by-carpooling-crackdown |archive-date=November 9, 2016 |dead-url=no |quote= |df= }}</ref> The odd-even license plate scheme is ti serve as a transitional regulation before an [[electronic road pricing]] system is implemented in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/25/ahok-expects-20-percent-fall-in-traffic-from-odd-even-policy.html |title=Ahok expects 20 percent fall in traffic from odd-even policy |author=Callistasia Anggun Wijaya |date=July 25, 2016 |website=The Jakarta Post |publisher=PT. Niskala Media Tenggara |access-date=November 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161109113715/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2016/07/25/ahok-expects-20-percent-fall-in-traffic-from-odd-even-policy.html |archive-date=November 9, 2016 |dead-url=no |quote= |df= }}</ref>
==History==
===Before Sudirman Road=== Sudirman Road and [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin|Thamrin Road]] were built between 1949 and 1953 with the purpose to connect the suburb [[Kebayoran Baru|Kebayoran]] with [[Central Jakarta]].{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=37}} The plan of Sudirman Road has been laid out at least since the colonial period in the 1930s as part of Batavia's street network expansion plan to the south of the [[Jakarta Flood Canal|west Flood Canal]]. The street planning that would become Sudirman Road is probably the only street planning south of the canal from the colonial period that was actually implemented after Indonesia's independence. The area where Sudirman Road would be laid were mainly kampung settlements, with rice plantation along the west bank of [[Krukut River]] and patches of coconut and fruit tree plantations.{{sfn|Herdruk Topografische Dienst Nederland|Koninklijk Instituut voor de Tropen|1930s}}
===1950s-1960s rural Sudirman Road=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Het aanleggen van de hoofdverkeersweg van Djakarta naar Kebajoran TMnr 60054772.jpg|thumb|left|Construction of the Sudirman road in 1950, then known simply as "road connection between Jakarta and Kebayoran".]] With the development of the [[Kebayoran Baru|Kebayoran]] suburb to the south of Jakarta, there was a need to construct a road connecting the new suburb with the city center. Construction of the road started immediately in 1949 and was largely completed in 1953. This nameless road was dubbed ''Kebayoran Road'' or simply ''weg naar Kebayoran Baru'' (Dutch "the road to Kebayoran Baru"){{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=90}} The new road is rural in quality, lacking planned development on both side of the road. With the nationalization of road names in late 1950s, the road received a name Djalan Raja Djendral Sudirman (General Sudirman Main Road) after a [[Sudirman|National Hero]]. Some high-profile events were held in Sudirman Road e.g. the ''Pekan Raya'' or international trade and entertainment fairs, held between 1953-1955 on the site where [[Atma Jaya University]] now stands. The ''Pekan Raya'' event was the precursor of the [[Jakarta Fair]]s that was held at Medan Merdeka Selatan from 1968 to 1991, before it was relocated to an area of the converted [[Kemayoran Airport]] in 1992, where they are still held today.{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=39}}
Developments along Sudirman Road was relatively slow compared with the fast development of [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin|Thamrin Road]]. In the 1960s, the only apparent development along Sudirman Road were the residential neighborhood of Benhil and Setiabudi, which was mostly planned for government workers. These residential neighborhoods was designed with access to Sudirman Road. Other than these residential neighborhoods, Sudirman Road was devoid of any commercial developments.{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=27}} In 1963, the sports event [[GANEFO]] was held using the Sudirman Road as the main access to the new [[Gelora Bung Karno|stadium]].
===1970s-1980s construction boom=== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Het centrum van Jakarta in de avonduren met kantoren en hotels TMnr 20018501.jpg|thumb|right|Sudirman Road in 1992.]] Only during the 1970s that the Sudirman Road began to experience signs of development along the road, which first appeared north of [[Semanggi cloverleaf interchange|Semanggi]]. Among the first office buildings to be built at Sudirman Road were Wisma Arthaloka (1976), Toyota Astra, Wisma Harapan, Wisma Benhil, [[Atma Jaya Catholic University of Indonesia|Atma Jaya University]], Wisma Metropolitan I, Hotel Sahid Jaya, [[Balai Sarbini|Balai Sarbini, and Gedung Veteran]] (Graha Purna Yudha, 1973). There was also a GKBI ''batik'' cooperatives building on the northwest corner of Semanggi; which would be replaced by Wisma GKBI office tower.{{sfn|Merrillees|2015|p=27}}
The late 1970s saw the construction of Gedung Panin, S. Widjoyo Center, and [[Ratu Plaza]] shopping complex.<ref name="secuil2"/>
The 1980s saw construction boom in Sudirman Road, among them were Prince Centre (Gedung Pangeran), Chase Plaza, Wisma Indocement, Wisma BCA, Summitmas Tower, Mid Plaza, Sentral Plaza, and Wisma Bumiputera.<ref name="secuil2">{{cite web|url=https://truelia.wordpress.com/2011/02/18/secuil-sejarah-pembangunan-jakarta-2/ |title=Secuil Sejarah Pembangunan Jakarta 2 |author=Amalia S. |date=February 18, 2011 |website=truelia.wordpress.com |publisher=Wordpress |dead-url=no |access-date=August 29, 2016 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160829113759/https://truelia.wordpress.com/2011/02/18/secuil-sejarah-pembangunan-jakarta-2/ |archive-date=August 29, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
===Present=== [[File:Sudirman Road 01.jpg|thumb|Sudirman Road in 2017]] On December 23, 2003, a "3-in-1" scheme was introduced for Sudirman Road by Governor [[Sutiyoso]] to deal with the worsening traffic. In February 2004, the Corridor 1 of [[TransJakarta]] Bus Rapid Transit was commercially opened. The new line transformed one lane of the Sudirman Road into a dedicated bus lane unaffected by traffic.
[[Jakarta Mass Rapid Transit]] project which commenced in the end of 2013 would transform Sudirman Road following a transit-oriented scheme. MRT entrances will be constructed at the widened sidewalk, which was done by transforming the slow lane into wider sidewalk. To reduce the congestion, an [[electronic road pricing]] system will be introduced in 2017 to Sudirman Road.
==See also== {{commons|Jalan Sudirman (Jakarta)}} *[[Jalan Gajah Mada and Jalan Hayam Wuruk]] *[[Menteng]] *[[History of Jakarta]]

==Cited works== *{{cite map |author1 =Herdruk Topografische Dienst Nederland |author2=Koninklijk Instituut voor de Tropen |title =Plattegrond van Batavia |trans-title =Map of Batavia |map =Jakarta |map-url =http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/4770134 |year =1930s |scale =1:20,000 |series = |publisher = |cartography = |page = |pages = |section = |sections = |inset = |edition = |location = |language =Dutch |format = |isbn = |id = |access-date =November 9, 2016 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Merrillees |first=Scott |date=2015 |title=Jakarta: Portraits of a Capital 1950-1980 |url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=akLWjgEACAAJ&dq=JAKARTA:+Portraits+of+a+Capital+1950-1980&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y |location=Jakarta |publisher=Equinox Publishing |isbn=9786028397308 |ref=harv}} {{Roads of Jakarta}} [[Category:Central business districts in Indonesia]] [[Category:Central Jakarta]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Captain | name = John Ames | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1738|04|07}} | birth_place = [[Bridgewater, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1805|6|17|1738|04|07}} | death_place = [[Bridgewater, Massachusetts]] | awards = | spouse = Susannah Howard | known_for = [[Ames Manufacturing Company]] founder | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = | occupation = Blacksmith | children = [[Oliver Ames Sr.|Oliver Ames, Sr.]]
[[David Ames (colonel)]] | relatives = [[Oliver Ames, Jr.]] (grandson)
[[Oakes Ames]] (grandson) }} '''Capt. John Ames''' (April 7, 1738 – June 17, 1805) was a [[Patriot (American Revolution)|patriot]], Captain in the [[American Revolutionary War]], [[gunsmith]], shovel maker, and ancestor of the [[Ames family]] of Easton, Massachusetts. == Biography == Capt. John Ames was born April 7, 1738, second son of Thomas and Keziah Howard. He married Susanna Howard in 1759 or 1757. Their children were: David, Keziah and Susanna, Huldah, Abigail, Cynthia, John, and [[Oliver Ames Sr.|Oliver Ames, Sr.]] === Blacksmith === Ames was a blacksmith in Bridgewater, Massachusetts. After the "nail and splitting mills" were outlawed by the government in Great Britain to give iron manufacturers in Britain a monopoly in 1773, Ames switched to making shovels. Despite having only a crude factory, he was able to make shovels of notable quality. In fact, he was said to have developed a shovel "so perfect that further improvement seems impossible." The remains of his trip hammer stone and man-made weirs and dams can be seen at [[War Memorial Park (West Bridgewater, Massachusetts)]]. === Revolutionary War === John Ames made guns for the Massachusetts army during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. During the war, Ames served in the Massachusetts Militia. In December 1776, the Militia was sent to [[Newport, RI]] to try and prevent British troops from securing a stronghold. John served 15 days alongside two of Washington's generals (one being [[Benedict Arnold]]). In June 1778, they returned to Newport to assist a French fleet in attacks against the British but were sent home after 24 days when the Continental Army under [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette]] did not arrive. The last documented service was in July, 1780, when Admiral de Ternay ([[Charles-Henri-Louis d'Arsac de Ternay]]) landed 6,000 French troops in Rhode Island and the Militia was sent to protect them from the British. He served as captain in Colonel Edward Mitchell's Regiment in 1776; as captain in Colonel Wade's Regiment, 1778; captain in Major Eliphalet Carey's Regiment, 1780; and Second Major of the 3d Regiment, 1780. Despite being promoted to major, he was known as "captain" for the rest of his life. Captain John Ames died July 17, 1803 in [[Bridgewater, Massachusetts]]. ==Ames family and legacy== The Ames family eventually became a very influential and wealthy family in Massachusetts, establishing two factories as well as having influence in the American railroad expansion and government. Capt. John's son David Ames (born 1760) was appointed by [[George Washington]] to be the first head of the [[Springfield Armory]]. Two factories were started by descendants of Capt. John Ames, in different regions of Massachusetts. Ames' son [[Oliver Ames, Sr.]] went on to found the [[Ames Shovel Shop]] in [[Easton, Massachusetts]]. Ames' descendants (grandchildren?), brothers James Tyler Ames and Nathan Peabody Ames, went on to found the [[Ames Manufacturing Company]] in [[Chicopee, Massachusetts]] in 1835.{{cite web|title=Stearns-Ames collection, [ca. 1838-1894]|url=http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/stearnsames-collection-9691|website=Archives of American Art|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=26 February 2016|quote=The Ames Manufacturing Company, Chicopee, Massachusetts, was founded in 1835 by James Tyler Ames and his brother, Nathan Peabody Ames}} His great-grandson [[Oliver Ames (governor)|Oliver Ames]] became governor of Massachusetts, 1887–1890. ==External links== *{{findagrave|55254413}} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite book|last1=Ames|first1=Winthrop|title=The Ames Family of Easton, Massachusetts|publisher=Private Print|pages=64-67}} {{cite book|title=Representative men and old families of southeastern Massachusetts|date=1912|publisher=J.H. Beers & Co.|page=26|edition=Vol I|url=https://archive.org/stream/representativeme01jhbe_0#page/40/mode/2up|accessdate=23 February 2016}} {{cite journal|last1=Clarke|first1=James W.|title=Oliver Ames|journal=The New England Magazine, Volume 2|date=1885|pages=186}} {{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=William T.|title=The New England States|publisher=D.H. Hurd & Co|location=Boston|pages=375–376|edition=Vol 1|url=https://archive.org/details/newenglandstates01davi|accessdate=20 February 2016}} {{cite book|title=Register of Members of the Society of Sons of the Revolution in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts|author=Society of the Sons of the Revolution in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts|date=1897|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BtAtAAAAYAAJ|page=62|quote=Major John Ames (1738-1805), Captain in Colonel Edward Mitchell's Regiment, 1776; Captain in Colonel Wade's Regiment, 1778; Captain in Major Eliphalet Carey's Regiment, 1780; Second Major of the 3d Regiment, 1780.}} {{cite book|title=Lineage Book, Volume 50|date=1919|publisher=Daughters of the American Revolution|page=334|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0YtAAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=22 February 2016|quote=John Ames was captain of a company of Plymouth County militia. He served under different commands in the defense of Rhode Island. He was a leading gunmaker and furnished arms for the troops. He was born and died in West Bridgewater, Mass.}} }} {{Griffon Corporation}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ames, John}} [[Category:1738 births]] [[Category:1805 deaths]] [[Category:American blacksmiths]] [[Category:People of Massachusetts in the American Revolution]] [[Category:Continental Army officers from Massachusetts]] [[Category:People from Bridgewater, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Butler–Ames family]]

{{Infobox person |name = John Barnett Hess |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|4|5}} |birth_place = |residence = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |alma_mater = B.A. [[Harvard College]]
M.B.A. [[Harvard Business School]] |nationality = [[United States]] |occupation = Businessman |known_for = CEO of [[Hess Corporation]] |salary = |networth = |spouse = Susan Elizabeth Kessler |children = |parents = Norma Wilentz Hess
[[Leon Hess]] |website = }} '''John Barnett Hess''' (born April 5, 1954)[http://www.nndb.com/people/337/000125959/ "Profile: John Hess"], [[NNDB]] is the CEO of [[Hess Corporation]]. ==Biography== John Hess was born in 1954 to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,[https://books.google.com/books?id=DGn8UMzI--8C&pg=PA116#v=onepage&q=hess&f=false ''We Are Many: Reflections On American Jewish History And Identity'' By Edward S Shapiro] pages 123-124 | retrieved April 6, 2013[http://obits.nj.com/obituaries/starledger/obituary.aspx?pid=142161735#fbLoggedOut New Jersey Star Ledger: "Norma Wilentz Hess"] April 22, 2010 the son of Norma and [[Leon Hess]]. His father was the founder of the [[Hess Oil and Chemical]] Company which later became the [[Amerada Hess Corporation]] and is now known as the [[Hess Corporation]]. His maternal grandfather was the former Attorney General [[David T. Wilentz]] who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the [[Lindbergh baby kidnapping]] case. He has two siblings: Marlene Hess and former [[Pennsylvania State Senator]], [[Constance H. Williams]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/08/sports/leon-hess-who-built-a-major-oil-company-and-owned-the-jets-is-dead-at-85.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm New York Times: "Leon Hess, Who Built a Major Oil Company and Owned the Jets, Is Dead at 85" By GERALD ESKENAZI] May 08, 1999 He earned his undergraduate degree from [[Harvard College]] in 1975 and his MBA from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1977. He married Susan Elizabeth Kessler in 1984.[https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/style/susan-e-kessler-exchanges-vows-with-john-hess.html "Susan E. Kessler Exchanges Vows With John Hess"], ''The New Yotk Times'', December 16, 1984 Hess became Chairman and CEO of [[Hess Corporation]] in 1995. He stepped down as Chairman in May 2013, retaining his position as CEO. {{cite web | title = Hess Chairman Cedes Title After 18 Years - WSJ.com | url = https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323744604578474612955157242 | accessdate = 2013-11-17 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Leon Hess]] | title=CEO of [[Amerada Hess Corporation]] | years= | after=incumbent }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hess, John B.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:People from Monmouth County, New Jersey]] [[Category:American people of Latvian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of Lithuanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Hess family]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] {{US-business-bio-1950s-stub}}

{{Infobox person | image = John Michael Kohler.jpg | alt = | caption = John Michael Kohler in 1873 | birth_date = November 3, 1844 | birth_place = [[Schnepfau]], [[Schnepfau]], [[Austria]] | death_date = {{D-da|November 5, 1900|November 3, 1844}} | death_place = [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin]], US | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = Founding of [[Kohler Company]] | spouse = {{plain list| *Elizabeth Vollrath *Wilhemina Vollrath}} }} '''John Michael Kohler II''' (November 3, 1844 – November 5, 1900) was member of the [[Kohler family of Wisconsin]] and was a prosperous industrialist and mayor of [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin]]. Kohler founded what later became known as the [[Kohler Company]], a large producer of bathroom and kitchen products.
==Early life== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2011}} Kohler was born on November 3, 1844 in the Alpine village of [[Schnepfau]], [[Austria]], the fourth child of dairy farmer John Michael Kohler Sr. (1805–74) and his wife, the former Maria Anna Moosbrugger (1816–53). After his wife's death, the elder Kohler remarried, and he and his large family emigrated to the United States. With help from a relative, the Kohlers built up a promising dairy business.
After a limited formal education, John Michael Kohler found work in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]. In 1865 he moved to [[Chicago, Illinois]] and became a traveling salesman. In [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin]], 56 miles north of [[Milwaukee]] on Lake Michigan, he met Lillie Vollrath (1848–1883), the daughter of local steel and iron industrialist [[Jacob Vollrath]] (1824–1898). The couple was married in 1871.
==Business career== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2011}} Shortly after his marriage, Kohler worked at the steel and iron factory his father-in-law partly owned. He took over the company two years later during the [[Panic of 1873]]. By the early 1880s, the firm was producing a variety of iron and enamelware products. In 1883, Kohler put ornamental feet on a cast-iron water trough and sold it as a bathtub. Four years later, more than two-thirds of the company's business was in plumbing products and enamelware. In 1888, Kohler and two partners had the firm incorporated.
In 1899, Kohler purchased 21 acres of farmland four miles west of Sheboygan, intending to move his entire company to the location. Shortly after the new factory was constructed, in 1900, Kohler died at 56, likely of heart failure.
Five years later, 30-year-old Walter J. Kohler assumed his father's corporate presidency and began to guide the firm. In 1912, it was officially designated the Kohler Company, and the property surrounding the plant became the Village of [[Kohler, Wisconsin|Kohler]].
==Civic leadership== From 1880 until his death Kohler served in several governmental offices. In 1892 he became Mayor. Citizens also admired Kohler for his generous contributions and leadership in the areas of art and culture, symbols of Sheboygan's desire to be more than a factory town.<ref name="Reeves">Thomas C. Reeves, Distinguished Service: The Life of Wisconsin Governor Walter J. Kohler, Jr. (Marquette University Press, 2006), pp. 19-29</ref>
The [[John Michael Kohler Arts Center]], which occupies a square block in downtown Sheboygan (containing Kohler's [[John Michael Kohler House|restored Gilded Age home]] along with modern buildings), is named for Kohler,<ref name="Blodgett">Richard E. Blodgett, A Sense of Higher Design: The Kohlers of Kohler (Greenwich Publishing Group, 2003)</ref><ref name="Kohler Experience">http://www.akohlerexperience.com/village/tours/art_center</ref> as is John Michael Kohler State Park, established on land donated in 1966 by the Kohler family.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dnr.wi.gov/topic/parks/name/kohlerandrae/history.html#Kohler |title=John Michael Kohler State Park |publisher=Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources |accessdate=August 5, 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2011}} The Kohlers had six children, including [[Walter Jodok Kohler, Sr.]] (1875-40), who would later be Governor of Wisconsin. In 1887, four years after his wife Lillie's death, John married Lillie's sister, Wilhelmina (Minnie) Vollrath (1852–1929), and they had one child, [[Herbert Vollrath Kohler Sr]] (1891–1968). This Kohler was to become the dominant force in the Kohler company for many years, presiding over the longest strike in American history.
The large and fashionable Kohler family home in Sheboygan was filled with music, books, and constant lessons in ethics and public service. The entire Sheboygan area mourned Kohler's 1900 death.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} John's three daughters remained in the Kohler house, unmarried, for the rest of their lives, frequently wearing black.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100929215946/http://www.vollrathco.com/profile_history.jsp Brief biography of Jacob J. Vollrath, Kohler's father-in-law]
{{Kohler Company}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kohler, John Michael}} [[Category:Kohler Company]] [[Category:People from Vorarlberg]] [[Category:People from Sheboygan, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Kohler family of Wisconsin]] [[Category:Mayors of Sheboygan, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Wisconsin]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1900 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]]

revision.comment: /* J Murphy & Sons */
revision.text:
'''John Murphy ''' (5 October 1913 – 7 May 2009) was an Irish business man who established the construction and infrastructure contractor J. Murphy & Sons. The company, based in [[Kentish Town]], with its green vans and lorries, works on building sites across the UK and Ireland.<ref name="Independent">{{cite news|last1=McCrystal|first1=Cal|title=These green vans are seen all over Britain, but no one knows anything about the millionaire who owns them|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/these-green-vans-are-seen-all-over-britain-but-no-one-knows-anything-about-the-millionaire-who-owns-1434519.html|work=The Independent|date=8 May 1994}}</ref> His late brother Joe also went into construction in London, trading as Murphy Ltd and using grey vehicles,<ref name="IndependentObit">{{cite news|last1=McKittrick|first1=David|title=John Murphy: Businessman whose name was synonymous with the construction industry|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/john-murphy-businessman-whose-name-was-synonymous-with-the-construction-industry-1686892.html|work=The Independent|date=18 May 2009}}</ref> but that company went into administration and closed in 2013.<ref name="Prior-24Oct2013">{{cite news|last1=Prior|first1=Grant|title=Grey Murphy in administration with 293 job losses|url=http://www.constructionenquirer.com/2013/10/24/civils-specialist-goes-into-administration/|accessdate=9 February 2018|work=Construction Enquirer|date=24 October 2013}}</ref>
==Biography== Murphy was born at Loughmark, near [[Cahersiveen]], [[County Kerry]]. He left school at 15 but found work hard to come by. He travelled to London and started up as a subcontractor in the building trade. The [[Second World War]] offered him a golden opportunity. New airfields were urgently needed and later on runway repairs were needed also.<ref name="TelegraphObit">{{cite news|title=John Murphy|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/finance-obituaries/5507923/John-Murphy.html|work=The Telegraph|date=11 June 2009}}</ref> He was successful in providing this service and at end of the war was well placed to help with large-scale reconstruction. Other ventures included [[electrification]], cable installation, water facilities and road-building.
At his death in 2009, his worth was estimated at about £190 million.<ref name="GuardianObit">{{cite news|last1=Harrison|first1=Gerry|title=John Murphy | Obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jun/23/obituary-john-murphy|work=The Guardian|date=22 June 2009}}</ref> He valued his privacy and was known to spend little on luxuries, instead preferring to spend time with his own workmen and other Irish friends.<ref name="Independent" />
==J Murphy & Sons== In the 1970s a specialist division of the company worked on the development of [[natural gas]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Murphy Group celebrates 60 great years in business|url=http://irishpost.co.uk/murphy-group-celebrates-60-great-years-in-business/|work=Irish Post|date=19 June 2012}}</ref> Later projects included the [[London Stansted Airport|Stansted Airport]] Rail Link, work in the [[City of London]], the [[Channel Tunnel Rail Link]] and [[London Olympic Park|London’s Olympic Park]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.murphygroup.co.uk/about-us/our-history/|website=Murphy Group|accessdate=4 November 2017|language=en}}</ref>
In 2007 J Murphy and Sons generated nearly £500 million of revenue and made pre-tax profits of £60 million. It was appointed lead contractor in the £125 million [[Liverpool]]-[[Manchester]] water pipeline project, which is to carry up to 100 million litres of water per day.<ref name="TelegraphObit" />
After Murphy's death in May 2009, leadership of the company passed initially to his daughter Caroline, who had been appointed deputy chairperson of the group in 2007.<ref name="Clifford">{{cite news|last1=Clifford|first1=Michael|title=Caroline Murphy and the Murphy Group - one woman's construction empire|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/features/caroline-murphy-and-the-murphy-group--one-womans-construction-empire-264319.html|accessdate=9 February 2018|work=Irish Examiner|date=5 April 2014}}</ref> She later planned to turn the business into a worker’s Co-op owned by its 3,500 employees, but other board members — notably her mother, brother and half-brother — resisted, and she resigned in 2014.<ref name="Clifford" />
The company was then led by Steve Hollingshead until the appointment in 2017 of John Murphy's grandson, John B Murphy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Founder’s grandson to lead J Murphy & Sons|url=http://www.constructionenquirer.com/2017/10/03/founders-grandson-to-lead-j-murphy-son/|work=Construction Enquirer|date=3 October 2017}}</ref>
In the year to 31 December 2017 the company made a pre-tax profit of £12.43m from a turnover of £711m, and had 3,878 employees. In 2018, it experienced a slow down in growth, and cancelled its Christmas Party as part of a cost-cutting drive affecting jobs across the business.<ref name="Prior-12Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Prior |first1=Grant |title=Murphy cancels Christmas party as job cuts loom |url=http://www.constructionenquirer.com/2018/10/12/murphy-cancels-christmas-party-as-job-cuts-loom/ |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Construction Enquirer |date=12 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Murphy, John}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:People from County Kerry]] [[Category:Civil engineering contractors]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{Property law}}
A '''lien''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|iː|n}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|iː|ən}}){{refn|The pronunciation {{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|iː|n}} is more common in both UK and US English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/english/lien|title=lien - definition of lien in English - Oxford Dictionaries|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=lien|title=The American Heritage Dictionary entry: lien|first=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing|last=Company|publisher=}}</ref>|group="Note"}} is a form of [[security interest]] granted over an item of [[property]] to secure the payment of a [[debt]] or performance of some other obligation. The owner of the property, who grants the lien, is referred to as the ''lienee''<ref>"Lienee...One whose property is subject to a lien". Black's Law Dictionary, p. 832 (5th ed. 1979).</ref> and the person who has the benefit of the lien is referred to as the ''lienor''<ref>"Lienor... The person having or owning a lien; one who has a right of lien upon property of another". Black's Law Dictionary, p. 832 (5th ed. 1979).</ref> or ''lien holder''.
The [[etymological]] root is Anglo-French ''lien'', ''loyen'' "bond", "restraint", from Latin ''ligamen'', from ''ligare'' "to bind".
In the [[United States]], the term lien generally refers to a wide range of [[encumbrance]]s and would include other forms of [[Mortgage law|mortgage]] or charge. In the US, a lien characteristically refers to ''[[Nonpossessory interest in land|nonpossessory]]'' security interests (see generally: [[Security interest#Security|Security interest—categories]]).
In other [[common-law]] countries, the term lien refers to a very specific type of security interest, being a passive right to retain (but not sell) property until the debt or other obligation is discharged. In contrast to the usage of the term in the US, in other countries it refers to a purely ''possessory'' form of security interest; indeed, when possession of the property is lost, the lien is released.<ref>''Hatton v Car Maintenance' [1915] 1 Ch 621</ref> However, common-law countries also recognize a slightly anomalous form of security interest called an "equitable lien" which arises in certain rare instances.
Despite their differences in terminology and application, there are a number of similarities between liens in the US and elsewhere in the common-law world.
==United States== Liens can be consensual or non-consensual (also termed voluntary or involuntary in different states). Consensual liens are imposed by a contract between the [[creditor]] and the debtor:
*[[mortgage law|mortgage]] *[[chattel mortgage]]
Nonconsensual liens typically arise by [[statute]] or by the [[operation of law|operation]] of the [[common law]]. Those laws give a creditor the right to impose a lien on an item of [[real property]] or a [[Personal property|chattel]] by the existence of the relationship of creditor and debtor. Those liens include
*[[Tax lien]]s, imposed to secure payment of a [[tax]]; *"Weed liens" and "Demolition liens", assessed by the government to rectify a property from being a nuisance and public hazard; *[[Homeowner Association]] (HOA) liens for unpaid assessments, fines, late charges, interest, costs, and attorney fees; *[[Lawyer|Attorney]]'s liens, against funds and documents to secure payment of fees; *[[Mechanic's lien]]s, which secure payment for work done on property or [[real property|land]]; *[[Judgment (law)|Judgment]] liens, imposed to secure payment of a judgment; and *[[Sea|Maritime]] liens, imposed on [[ship]]s by [[admiralty law]].
Liens are also "perfected" or "unperfected" (see [[perfection (law)|perfection]]). Perfected liens are those liens for which a creditor has established a priority right in the encumbered property with respect to third party creditors. Perfection is generally accomplished by taking steps required by law to give third party creditors notice of the lien. The fact that an item of property is in the hands of the creditor usually constitutes perfection. Where the property remains in the hands of the debtor, some further step must be taken, like recording a notice of the security interest with the appropriate office.
Perfecting a lien is an important part of the task of protecting the secured creditor's interest in the property. A perfected lien is valid against bona fide purchasers of property, and even against a [[trustee]] in [[bankruptcy]]; an unperfected lien may not be.
===Equitable lien (U.S.)=== In the United States, references to an "equitable lien" is a right, enforceable only in [[Equity (law)|equity]], to have a demand satisfied out of a particular fund or specific property without having possession of the fund or property. An equitable lien is actually a [[legal remedy]], rather than a security interest created in contemplation of or in support of a transaction. In U.S. law, such liens characteristically arise in four circumstances:<ref>''Black's Law Dictionary'' (8th ed.)</ref> # when an occupant of land, believing in good faith to be the owner of the land, makes improvements, repairs or other expenditure that permanently increases the land's value; # when one of two or more joint owners makes expenditures of the kind described above; # when a [[Life estate|tenant for life]] completes permanent and beneficial improvements to the estate begun earlier by the [[testator]]; and # when land or other property is transferred subject to the payment of debts, legacies, portions or [[Annuity (financial contracts)|annuities]] to third persons.
===Mover's lien=== [[moving company|Movers]] are typically entitled to a '''mover's lien''' under [[Uniform Commercial Code|UCC]] § 7-307/308, to withhold a customer's [[Personal property|goods]] to secure payment. This is a '''possessory lien''', and is the non-consensual type of lien (because it exists automatically under a statute instead of being affirmatively agreed upon). However, the concept of a mover's lien is often abused in a [[moving scam]] known as a '''hostage load''', whereby the moving company will [[fraud]]ulently [[extortion|extort]] money not owed by the customer by refusing to deliver the goods unless the customer pays money inflated beyond the [[contract]]ual [[sales quote|estimate]]. Because the customer has an interest in obtaining their own goods, they are under duress to pay the ransom. Hostage loads in at least the interstate context are illegal under [[Title 49 of the United States Code|49 U.S.C.]] 13905. The [[Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration|FMCSA]] regulates the moving industry and sometimes takes enforcement action by fining and/or delicensure of offending moving companies. Moving companies that deliberately engage in hostage-loading may also be considered to be engaging in [[racketeering]] in violation of the [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]].
Disputes between legitimate lienholding of chattels vs. hostage-loading can sometimes be averted by the customer including an advanced (before-the-fact) consensual waiver of the mover's right to a lien in the written contract, obligating the moving company to deliver the goods with '''reasonable dispatch''' regardless of disputes over payment, and failure to do so would constitute [[conversion (law)|conversion]] or [[trespass to chattels]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mondaq.com/unitedstates/x/157884/Transport%20Law%20Regulations/Holding%20Freight%20Hostage%20The%20Legal%20Wild%20West%20of%20the%20Transportation%20Industry|title=Holding Freight Hostage: The Legal Wild West Of The Transportation Industry - Transport - United States|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/rulemaking/2012-25678|title=Regulations|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/ucc/7/part_3|title=PART 3. BILLS OF LADING: SPECIAL PROVISIONS|first=LII|last=Staff|date=20 November 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
==Other common-law countries== Outside of the US, a common-law lien may be defined in general terms as a passive right to retain a chattel (and, in certain cases, documentary intangibles and papers) conferred by law. Modern law has generally left the legal lien to cases where it has been historically established without any real effort being made to make it applicable to modern conditions. In ''Tappenden v Artus'' [1964] 2 QB 185 Diplock LJ referred to a lien as a "self help" remedy, like "other primitive remedies such as abatement of nuisance, self-defence or ejection of trespassers to land". Equitable liens are an unusual species of property right, usually considered ''[[sui generis]]''.
===Common-law lien=== Common-law liens are divided into ''special liens'' and ''general liens''. A special lien, the more common kind, requires a close connection between the property and the service rendered. A special lien can only be exercised in respect of fees relating to the instant transaction; the lienor cannot use the property held as security for past debts as well. A general lien affects all of the property of the lienee in the possession of the lienor, and stands as security for all of the debts of the lienee to the lienor. A special lien can be extended to a general lien by contract, and this is commonly done in the case of carriers.<ref>''George Baker Ltd v Eynon'' [1974] 1 WLR 462</ref> A common-law lien only gives a passive right to retain; there is no power of sale which arises at common law,<ref>''Thames Iron Works v Patent Derrick'' (1860) 1 J&H 93</ref> although some statutes have also conferred an additional power of sale,<ref>In the United Kingdom, see for example, Innkeepers Act 1878</ref> and it is possible to confer a separate power of sale by contract.
The common-law liens are closely aligned to the so-called "common callings", but are not co-extensive with them.
A common-law lien is a very limited type of security interest. Apart from the fact that it only amounts to a passive right to retain, a lien cannot be transferred;<ref>''Legg v Evans'' (1840) 6 M&W 36</ref> it cannot be asserted by a third party to whom possession of the goods is given to perform the same services that the original party should have performed;<ref>''Pennington v Reliance Motors Ltd'' [1923] 1 KB 127</ref> and if the chattel is surrendered to the lienor, the lien entitlement is lost forever<ref>''Hatton v Car Maintenance'' [1915] 1 Ch 621</ref> (except for where the parties agree that the lien shall survive a temporary re-possession by the lienor). A lienee who sells the chattel unlawfully may be liable in conversion as well as surrendering the lien.<ref>''Mulliner v Florence (1878) 3 QBD 484</ref>
===Equitable lien=== In common-law countries, equitable liens give rise to unique and difficult issues. An equitable lien is a nonpossessory security right conferred by operation of law, which is similar in effect to an [[equitable charge]]. It differs from a charge in that it is non-consensual. It is conferred only in very limited circumstances, the most common (and least ambiguous) of which is in relation to the sale of land; an unpaid vendor has an equitable lien over the land for the purchase price, notwithstanding that the purchaser has gone into occupation of the property. It is seen as a counterweight to the equitable rule which confers a beneficial interest in the land on the purchaser once contracts are exchanged for purchase.
It is a matter of conjecture how far equitable liens extend outside of the unpaid vendor's lien. Equitable liens have been held to exist in a number of cases involving [[chose in action|choses in action]], but not yet in relation to chattels.<ref>''Transport and General Credit v Morgan'' [1939] 2 All ER 17</ref> The Australian courts have been the most receptive towards equitable liens in relation to personal property (see ''Hewett v Court'' (1983) 57 ALJR 211, but a review of the cases still leaves a lack of clarity in relation to the principles upon which an equitable lien will be imposed. * In ''Re Stucley'' [1906] 1 Ch 67 a vendor of a reversionary interest in a trust fund, who sold the interest to the trustee, was held to have an equitable lien in the subject matter, although it was clearly personalty and not realty. * In ''Barker v Cox'' (1876) 4 Ch D 464 the purchaser of property which was included in a matrimonial settlement paid the price in advance to one of the trustees, and the purchaser was held to have an equitable lien in investments which the trustees subsequently acquired with the purchase price. * In ''Langen and Wing v Bell'' [1972] Ch 685 a [[board of directors|director's]] service agreement required him to assign his shares in the [[company (law)|company]] if he was terminated, and he was to receive a price calculated at a later date when the annual accounts were available; he was held to have an equitable lien over the transferred shares to secure the payment of the eventual purchase price. * In ''Lord Napier & Etterick v Hunter'' [1993] 2 WLR 42 it was held that an indemnity insurer's [[subrogation]] rights in relation to funds improperly paid directly to the insured were subject to an equitable lien. But overall, there is still perceived to be a lack of central nexus.<ref>See Phillips J, "Equitable Liens—A search for a unifying principle" in Palmer & McKendrick, ''Interests in Goods'' (2nd ed.)</ref>
===Statutory liens and contractual liens=== Although arguably not liens as such, two other forms of encumbrance are sometimes referred to as liens.
====Statutory liens==== Certain statutes provide for a passive right to retain property against its owner as security for obligations. For example, section 88 of the [[Civil Aviation Act 1982]] of the United Kingdom permits an airport to detain aircraft for unpaid airport charges and aviation fuel. Although this right has been treated as a lien under UK insolvency law,<ref name="ReferenceA">''Bristol Airport v Powdrill'' [1990] Ch 744</ref> it has been argued that such statutory rights are not in fact liens, but rights analogous to liens,<ref name="ReferenceB">Michael Bridge, ''Personal Property Law'' (2nd ed.)</ref> although some might say that this is a distinction without a difference{{who|date=April 2014}}.
====Contractual liens==== It has also been argued that an agreement by contract that one party may retain the goods of another party until paid is not a lien,<ref name="ReferenceB"/> as under the common law, liens could only be non-consensual. However, it appears that under insolvency law, such rights will be treated as liens even if they are not expressed to be liens.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Maritime liens==<!-- This section is linked from [[Admiralty law]] --> {{main|Maritime lien}} A '''maritime lien''' is a lien on a vessel, given to secure the claim of a creditor who provided maritime services to the vessel or who suffered an injury from the vessel's use. Maritime liens are sometimes referred to as ''tacit hypothecation''. Maritime liens have little in common with other liens under the laws of most jurisdictions.
The maritime lien has been described as "one of the most striking peculiarities of [[Admiralty law]]".<ref name="Griffith Price 1940">Griffith Price, ''The Law of Maritime Liens'' (1940)</ref> A maritime lien constitutes a security interest upon ships of a nature otherwise unknown to the common law or equity. It arises purely by [[operation of law]] and exists as a claim upon the property concerned, both secret and invisible, often given priority by statute over other forms of registered security interest.<ref>''Bankers Trust v Todd Shipyards, The Halcyon Isle'' [1981] AC 221</ref> Although characteristics vary under the laws of different countries, it can be described as: # a privileged claim, # upon maritime property, # for service to it or damage done by it, # accruing from the moment that the claim attaches, # travelling with the property unconditionally, # enforced by an action ''[[in rem]]''.<ref name="Griffith Price 1940"/>
==Nomenclature==
Throughout the world, there are a large number of different types and sub-divisions of liens. Not all of the following liens exist in all legal systems that recognise the concept of a lien. The following are descriptions that are not necessarily mutually exclusive. Types of lien include
* ''accountant's lien''—the right of an [[accountant]] to retain a client's papers until the accountant's fees have been paid.<ref name="Millichamp2002">{{cite book|author=A. H. Millichamp|title=Auditing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K1E681Cy51AC&pg=PA141|year=2002|publisher=Cengage Learning EMEA|isbn=0-8264-5500-X|pages=141–}}</ref> * ''agent's lien'' * ''agister's lien''—the lien of an [[agistment|agister]] over animals in the agister's care as security for fees. * ''agricultural lien'' (United States)—a statutory lien that protects the seller of farming equipment by giving the seller a lien on crops grown with the equipment. * ''architect's lien''—the right of an [[architect]] to retain a client's papers until the architect's fees have been paid. * ''attachment lien''—a lien on property seized by [[pre-judgment attachment]]. * ''attorney's lien''—the right of an [[Lawyer|attorney]] to retain a client's papers until the attorney's fees have been paid (also referred to as a ''charging lien'', ''solicitor's lien'' or a ''retaining lien'' in some jurisdictions. * ''[[banker's lien]]''—the right of a [[bank]] to satisfy a customer's matured debt by seizing the customer's money or property within the bank's possession. * ''blanket lien''—a lien that gives the lienor the entitlement to take possession of any or all of the lienee's real property to cover a delinquent loan. * ''carrier's lien''—a carrier's right to retain possession of [[cargo]] until the owner of the cargo pays shipping costs. * ''choate lien'' (United States)—a lien in which the lienee, the property, and the monetary amount are established so that the lien is [[perfection (law)|perfected]] and nothing else needs to be done to make the lien [[enforceable]]. * ''common-law lien''—a lien arising under the common law, rather than by [[statute]], [[Equity (law)|equity]] or agreement between the parties. * ''concurrent lien''—means one of two or more liens over the same property. * ''consummate lien'' (United States)—a judgment lien arising after the denial of motion for a new trial. * ''conventional lien'' (United States)—a lien that is created by agreement between the parties, in circumstances where the law would not otherwise create a lien. * ''deferred lien'' (United States)—a lien that only take effect from a future date. * ''demurrage lien''—a carrier's lien on goods for any unpaid [[demurrage]] charges. * ''dragnet lien'' (United States)—a lien that is enlarged to cover any additional credit extended to the debtor to the same creditor. * ''environmental lien''—A charge, security, or encumbrance on a property's title to secure payment of cost or debt arising from response actions, cleanup, or other remediation of hazardous substances or petroleum products. * ''equitable lien''—a lien that is enlarged to cover any additional credit extended to the debtor to the same creditor. * ''execution lien''—a lien on property seized by levy of execution. * ''factor's lien''—a lien, usually statutory, on property held on consignment by a [[Factoring (finance)|factor]]. * ''first lien''—a lien that takes priority over all other encumbrances over the same property. * ''floating lien'' (United States)—a lien that is expanded to cover any additional property that is acquired by the lienee while the debt is outstanding (in common-law countries, see [[Floating charge]]). * ''garnishment lien''—a lien on the debtor's property held by a [[Garnishment|garnishee]]. * ''general lien''—a possessory lien by which the lien holder may retain any of the debtor's goods in the lien holder's possession until any debt due from the debtor, whether in connection with the retained goods or otherwise, has been paid. Factors, insurance brokers, packers, stockbrokers and banker's liens are all usually general liens. * ''healthcare lien'' (United States)—a statutory lien asserted by an [[HMO]], insurer, medical group or independent practice association against those liable to the, also its patient in damages, to recover money paid or claim money payable for healthcare services provided (sometimes called a ''healthcare lien''). * ''hospital lien'' (United States)—a statutory lien asserted by a [[hospital]] to recover the costs of emergency and other ongoing medical and other services. * ''hotelkeeper's lien''—a possessory or statutory lien allowing an innkeeper to hold, as security for payment, personal property that a guest has brought into the [[hotel]] (also referred to as an ''innkeeper's lien''). * ''[[inchoate lien]]''—a lien that may be defeated if the relevant judgment is vacated or a motion for a new trial is granted. * ''involuntary lien''—a lien arising without the lienee's consent. * ''judgment lien''—a lien imposed on a judgment debtor's non-exempt property. * ''judicial lien''—a lien obtained by judgment, levy, sequestration or other legal or equitable process or proceeding. * ''junior lien''—a lien that is junior or subordinate to another lien on the same property. * ''landlord's lien''—a lien which empowered a landlord to seize a tenant's property and sell it to satisfy overdue rent. * ''manufacturer's lien''—a statutory lien that secures payment for labour or materials expended in producing goods for another. * ''[[maritime lien]]''—see above. * ''[[mechanic's lien]]''—(also sometimes referred to as an ''artisan's lien'', ''chattel lien'', ''construction lien'', ''labourer's lien'', in various jurisdictions). * ''mineral lien''-a lien on working interest that secures payment for labor or materials expended by oilfield service companies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brister|first=Austin|title=MINERAL LIENS: COLLECTING UNPAID DEBT FOR OILFIELD SERVICE COMPANIES|url=http://www.oilandgaslawdigest.com/back-to-basics/mineral-liens-collecting-unpaid-debt-oilfield-service-companies/|publisher=OilandGasLawDigest.com|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref> * ''mortgage lien''—a lien on the mortgagor's property securing the [[Mortgage loan|mortgage]]. * ''municipal lien'' (United States)—a lien by a [[municipal corporation]] against a property owner for the owner's proportional share of a public improvement that specifically and individually benefits the owner. * ''possessory lien''—a lien allowing the creditor to keep possession of the encumbered property until the debt is satisfied. * ''second lien''—a lien that is next in rank after a first lien on the same property. * ''secret lien''—a lien not appearing of record and unknown to the purchasers; a lien reserved by the vendor and kept hidden from third parties to secure the payment of goods after delivery.<ref>{{cite web |ssrn=1323190 |author=M Simkovic |title=Secret Liens and the Financial Crisis of 2008 |publisher=Social Science Research Network (SSRN) |year=2009 |accessdate=June 29, 2011 }}</ref> * ''[[Solicitor's lien]]''—the right of a [[solicitor]] to recover his [[costs (England and Wales)|costs]] from a client. It is broader than a conventional lien. * ''special lien''—a possessory lien by which the possessor of goods has the right to retain specific goods until a debt incurrent in connection with the goods has been paid (also referred to as a ''particular lien''). The opposite of a ''general lien''. * ''statutory lien''—a lien arising solely by force of statute. * ''[[tax lien]]''—a lien on property and all rights to property imposed by the taxing authority for unpaid taxes. * ''vendee's lien''—a buyer's lien on the purchased land as security for repayment of purchase money paid in, enforceable if the seller cannot or does not convey good title. * ''vendor's lien''—a seller's lien on land as security for the purchase price (sometimes called an ''unpaid vendor's lien''). * ''voluntary lien''—a lien created with the lienee's consent. * ''warehouser's lien''—a lien for storage charges for goods stored with a [[bailment|bailee]] (sometimes called a ''warehouseman's lien''). * ''workers' compensation lien''—a statutory lien, asserted by a healthcare provider, to recover the cost of emergency and ongoing medical work, usually asserted against any workers'-compensation benefits paid to a patient.
==See also== * [[Bottomry]] * [[Detinue]] * [[False lien]] * [[Mechanic's lien]] * [[Mortgage]] * [[Replevin]] * [[Repossession]] * [[Security interest#Legal lien|Security interest—lien]] * [[Tax lien]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|group="Note"}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Use Australian English|date=June 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} '''Minister for Small Business''' is a position in the [[government of Western Australia]], currently held by [[Paul Papalia]] of the [[Australian Labor Party (Western Australian Branch)|Labor Party]]. The position was first created in 1984, for the government of [[Brian Burke (Australian politician)|Brian Burke]], and has existed in most governments since then. The minister is responsible for the state government's Small Business Development Corporation.
==Titles== * 20 December 1984 – present: Minister for Small Business

{{use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | image =Abd ar-Rahman ibn Nasir as-Sa'di and Mishaal bin Abdulaziz.jpg | caption = Mishaal first from the right | birth_date = 5 September 1926 | birth_place = [[Riyadh]], [[Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|5|3|1926|09|05|df=y}} | death_place = Riyadh, [[Saudi Arabia]] | title = Prince Mishaal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | mother = Shahida | father = [[Ibn Saud]] | module = {{Infobox royalty| embed = yes | spouse = | issue = | full name = Mishaal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | styles = | succession = Chairman of the [[Allegiance Council]] | reign = 2007–2017 | reign-type = In office | reg-type = Monarch | regent = [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdullah]]
[[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman]] | predecessor = ''Office established'' | successor = | succession2 = Governor of [[Makkah Province]] | reign2 = 1963–1971 | reign-type2 = In office | reg-type2 = Monarch | regent2 = [[King Saud]]
[[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|King Faisal]] | predecessor2 = Abdullah bin Saud bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | successor2 = [[Fawwaz bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud|Fawwaz bin Abdulaziz]] | succession3 = [[Minister of Defense (Saudi Arabia)|Minister of Defense]] | reign3 = 1951–1953 | reign-type3 = In office | reg-type3 = Monarch | regent3 = [[Ibn Saud]]
[[Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Saud]] | predecessor3 = [[Mansour bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] | successor3 = [[Fahad bin Saud bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] | house = [[House of Saud]] | death_date = | religion = [[Wahhabi]] [[Hanbali]] [[Sunni Islam]] }} }} '''Mishaal bin Abdulaziz al Saud''' ({{Lang-ar|مشعل بن عبد العزيز آل سعود}} ''Misha`al bin `Abd al-`Azīz as-Saʻūd''; 5 September 1926 – 3 May 2017) was chairman of the [[Allegiance Council]] and a senior member of the [[House of Saud]]. He held different cabinet posts in the 1950s. ==Early life== Prince Misha'al was born on 5 September 1926.{{Cite news |url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/1094266/saudi-arabia |title=Prince Mishal bin Abdulaziz passes away at 90 |last=Al-Sulami |first=Mohammad |access-date=4 May 2017 |work=Arab News |publication-date=4 May 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+Allegiance+Council.-a0272373988 |title=Saudi Arabian royal succession |date=14 November 2011 |publisher=APS Diplomat News Service |language=English |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130411223309/http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+Allegiance+Council.-a0272373988 |archive-date=11 April 2013 |dead-url=no |access-date=16 March 2013 |quote=Prince Mish'al, born in 1926 |df= }} He was the thirteenth son of [[Ibn Saud]].{{cite journal|last=Mouline|first=Nabil|title=Power and generational transition in Saudi Arabia|journal=Critique Internationale|date=April–June 2012|volume=46|pages=1–22|url=http://www.ceri-sciencespo.com/publica/critique/46/ci46_nm.pdf|accessdate=24 April 2012}} He was the full brother of [[Mansour bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Prince Mansour]], [[Mutaib bin Abdul-Aziz|Prince Mutaib]] and Princess Qumash who died on 26 September 2011.{{cite web|title=Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques performs funeral prayer on the soul of Princess Gumash bint Abdulaziz|url=http://www.alriyadh.gov.sa/en/news/Pages/news8273.aspx|publisher=Riyadh Municipality|accessdate=12 August 2012|date=27 September 2011}} Their mother was the Lebanese-born, Shahida, (died 1938),{{Cite web |url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/viewBio.do?id=176545 |title=Biography of Shahida |website=Datarabia |url-access=subscription |access-date=10 August 2012}} who reportedly was the favorite wife of Ibn Saud.{{cite book|last=Kechichian|first=Joseph A.|title=Succession in Saudi Arabia|year=2001|publisher=Palgrave|location=New York City|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=79Fs5bLPgBYC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=succession+in+saudi+arabia&source=bl&ots=YFljq6DjSQ&sig=jUyMCiI4Fo3DWpozWA8fR6pC9jY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=CuZ-T7bEK9Gp0AWAuoGTBw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=succession%20in%20saudi%20arabia&f=false}}{{cite web|last=Henderson|first=Simon|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/uploads/Documents/pubs/PolicyFocus96.pdf|title=After King Abdullah|work=Washington Institute|accessdate=28 July 2012|format=Policy Paper|date=August 2009}} ==Career== Prince Mishaal served as the Minister of Defense from 12 May 1951 to 1953.{{cite web|title=Land Forces History|url=http://rslf.gov.sa/English/aboutus/pages/overview.aspx|work=Royal Saudi Land Forces (RSLF)|accessdate=12 May 2012}}{{cite web|last=Kapoor|first=Talal|title=Nayif's Departure: Spring Cleaning in The Royal Court?|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/home.do;jsessionid=70AD079602B157A59264B8CD3893B7C0|work=Datarabia|accessdate=10 June 2012|date=8 June 2012}} He replaced his full brother Prince Mansour as minister of defense when he died of alcohol poisoning after a party hosted by then-Riyadh governor [[Nasser bin Abdulaziz]] in 1951.{{cite web|title=The new successıon law preserves the monarchy|url=https://wikileaks.org/cable/2006/11/06RIYADH8921.html#|work=Wikileaks|accessdate=21 April 2012|date=22 November 2006}} Until that date, Prince Mishaal served as deputy minister of defense. When he became minister, his younger full brother [[Mutaib bin Abdul-Aziz|Prince Mutaib]] was appointed his deputy. As minister of defense, he became one of the most affluent princes in the [[Al Saud]] family. He bought state land for very cheap prices and yielded extraordinary profits.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} But because of his lack of education and experience, Prince Mishaal let the ministry remain completely unorganized. He leaned heavily on advice and recommendation from foreign counsel. He wielded significant influence in Ibn Saud's government. Because of Mishaal's considerable power, Ibn Saud countered his influence by appointing [[Abdallah al Faisal|Abdullah bin Faisal]] as minister of health and interior. At the same time, [[Ibn Saud]] established the ministry of air force under Prince Mishaal to prevent flight-related matters from going under [[Talal bin Abdul Aziz|Prince Talal]], the then minister of communication. Since Mishaal and Talal could not agree, Saudi Arabia was to have two airline fleets. But in April 1955, Prince Talal resigned and the ministry of communication was merged with ministry of finance.{{cite book|author=S. Hertog|title=Princes Brokers and Bureaucrats|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YNM4vMi7FtcC&pg=PA46|accessdate=15 January 2013|date=23 February 2011|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-5753-1|page=46}} In May 1955, [[Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Saud]] created a renewed modern [[Saudi National Guard|National Guard]]. This was led by Saud's son Prince Khalid who replaced a commoner. This move weakened Prince Mishaal because he had often used the old National Guard's resources. ==Other positions== Mishaal and his full-brother Mutaib were ousted from the office under [[Saud of Saudi Arabia|King Saud]] but they returned to favour in 1963 under regent and later [[Faisal of Saudi Arabia|King Faisal]] who entrusted them a key governorship and deputy governorship, respectively. Specifically, Mishaal served as Governor of [[Makkah Province]] from 1963 to 1971. Both Mishaal and Mutaib resigned from their posts in 1971 for reasons that are not entirely clear. Prince Mishaal was appointed chairman of [[Allegiance Council|the Allegiance Council]] on 10 December 2007.{{cite news|title=Prince Mishaal to head Allegiance Commission: Saudi launches royal succession committee|url=http://www.26sep.net/nprint.php?lng=english&sid=35735|accessdate=10 November 2012|work=Al Arabiya|date=10 December 2007}} ===Succession to the throne=== Mishaal bin Abdulaziz protested more than once that he should have been crown prince since he served as both a governor and a minister and was older than some of his brothers. Mishaal's firm, Mishaal International, along with its German and Chinese partners, is the leading contender to build much of the Kingdom's new multibillion-dollar railway system. On the other hand, it is argued that he was immediately excluded from the competition for the title of crown prince by the [[Sudairi Seven|Sudairi brothers]]. ===Influence=== Mishaal bin Abdulaziz was impartial in family politics, although he was known to incline towards [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|King Abdallah]] or be one of King Abdullah's close allies. His neutral stance made him the perfect choice to be the chairman of the Allegiance Council. This role was considered to be a significant position, giving him influence in the decision-making process in regard to succession.{{cite web|author=Talal Kapoor|title=Briefing: Prince Mish'al's Health Condition|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/viewCommentary.do?id=14513|work=Datarabia|accessdate=11 May 2012|date=7 July 2010}} ==Business activities== Mishaal bin Abdulaziz was a leading businessman, with substantial investments in real estate, insurance, electrical utilities, oil trading and cement manufacture. He was founder of [[Al Shoula Group]], which is a major investor in real estate developments throughout the Middle East partnering with such investors as Dubai's [[Emaar]] Group, Kuwait's Bayt Al Mal Investment Company, and the [[Al Rajhi Bank|Al Rajhi family's]] Tameer Group. Al Shoula's wholly owned subsidiary, Dhahran Global, is active in broad areas of the petroleum and petrochemical industry including pipeline development, oil and gas production, oilfield services and international product trading.{{cite web|title=Al Shoula Group|url=http://dhahran-global.com/v1/main/press/shoulagroup.html|work=Dhahran Global Company|accessdate=29 May 2012}} The CEO of Al Shoula Group was his son Prince Abdulaziz. Prince Mishaal was also chairman of the board of Yanbu Cement company, established in 1976.{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.yanbucement.com/history.html|work=Yanbu Cement Company|accessdate=29 May 2012}} ==Personal life == Mishaal bin Abdulaziz was a supporter of the traditional [[camel racing]] and horse racing, and had valuable racing camels and horses. Each year, he patronized camel races in the kingdom. He also dealt with traditional falconry.[[:de:Mischal ibn Abd al-Aziz|Mischal ibn Abd al-Aziz]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=August 2015}} [[Abdul Aziz bin Fahd]] married Al Anoud bint Faisal Al Saud in December 2010.{{cite web|title=The Crown Prince of Dubai to attend the wedding of Prince Abdulaziz bin Fahd Al Saud|url=http://fazza.ae/en/2010/12/22/the-crown-prince-of-dubai-to-attend-the-wedding-of-prince-abdulaziz-bin-fahd-al-saud/|publisher=Fazza|accessdate=6 June 2012}} She is the granddaughter of Prince Mishaal.{{cite news|title=الأمير عبد العزيز بن فهد يحتفل بزواجه من كريمة الأمير فيصل بن مشعل|url=http://www.alriyadh.com/2010/12/23/article588103.html|accessdate=6 June 2012|newspaper=Al Riyadh|date=23 December 2010}} In October 2009, Mishaal bin Abdulaziz was rushed to hospital in [[Geneva]], apparently having suffered a stroke. Then, he returned to Saudi Arabia from unspecified medical treatment in [[Beirut]] in December 2009. Mishaal died on 3 May 2017 at the age of 90 according to the official Saudi Press Agency.{{Cite news |url=http://gulfbusiness.com/saudi-king-salmans-brother-prince-mishaal-dies/ |title=Saudi King Salman’s brother Prince Mishaal dies |access-date=4 May 2017 |work=Gulf Business |publication-date=4 May 2017 }}[https://al-marsd.com/126085.html وفاة الأمير مشعل بن عبدالعزيز رحمه الله]{{Cite news |url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/king-salman-s-brother-prince-mishaal-dies-aged-93-1.2021736 |title=King Salman's brother Prince Mishaal dies aged 93 |access-date=4 May 2017 |work=GulfNews.com |publication-date=3 May 2017}} ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |ref={{cite web|title=Family Tree of Mish'al bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abd al-Rahman Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176682|accessdate=8 May 2017|language=English}} |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Mishaal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud''' |2= 2. [[Ibn Saud|Abdulaziz ibn Saud]] |3= 3. Shahida |4= 4. [[Abdul Rahman bin Faisal]] |5= 5. Sarah bint Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed Al Sudairi |8= 8. [[Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud]] |9= 9. Sarah bint Mishari bin Abdulrahman bin Hassan Al Saud |10= 10. Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed bin Turki Al Sudairi |16= 16. [[Turki bin Abdullah bin Muhammad]] |17= 17. Hia bint Hamad bin Ali Al Faqih Angari Tamimi |18= 18. Mishari bin Abdulrahman bin Hassan Al Saud |20= 20. Mohammed bin Turki bin Suleiman Al Sudairi }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130927165633/http://www.princemishal.com/ar/default.aspx Mishaal bin Abdulaziz Official website] {{Sons of ibn Saud}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saud, Mishaal bin Abdulaziz Al}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Government ministers of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Governors of provinces in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian billionaires]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:Sons of Ibn Saud|Mishaal]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Nikollë Bojaxhiu | image = Nikollë Bojaxhiu.GIF | image_size = 150px | caption = | birth_date = {{Circa|1874}} | birth_place = [[Prizren]], [[Kosovo Vilayet]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | death_date = {{Circa|1919}} | death_place = [[Skopje#Ottoman period|Skopje]], [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] | occupation = Businessman | spouse = Dranafile Bernai | parents = Lazar Bojaxhiu | children = Aga
Lazar
[[Mother Teresa|Anjezë]] (Mother Teresa) }} '''Nikollë Bojaxhiu''' ({{circa|1874}} – {{circa|1919}}) was an [[Albanian people|Albanian]] businessman, benefactor, politician and the father of the Roman Catholic nun and missionary [[Mother Teresa]]. His company constructed the first theater of [[Skopje|Üsküb]] (now Skopje) and participated in the development of the railway line that connected [[Kosovo]] with Skopje – a project which he personally financed. An active Albanian rights activist, he was also the only [[Roman Catholic|Catholic]] to be elected to the city council of Skopje. Bojaxhiu died in 1919 in obscure circumstances, which led to reports that attributed his death to poisoning by Serbian agents. His children included Lazar, and Agnes Bojaxhiu ([[Mother Teresa]]). == Life == Nikollë was born in 1874 in [[Prizren]] to Lazër and Çilja Bojaxhiu. Bojaxhiu moved to Skopje in the [[Kosovo Vilayet]] (present-day [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]) after 1900, where he first worked as a pharmacist and later became a partner in a construction company.{{cite book|last1=Maasburg|first1=Leo|last2=Miller|first2=Michael J.|title=Mother Teresa of Calcutta: A Personal Portrait|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N4UxVZNER5EC&pg=PA71|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=2011-10-01|publisher=Ignatius Press|isbn=9781586175559|pages=71–}} He was a polyglot; as well as Albanian he also spoke [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]], [[Serbo-Croatian|Serbo-Croat]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]]. In the early 1900s, he married Dranafile Bernai with whom he had three children: Aga (b. 1905), Lazar (b. 1908) and Agnes (b. 1910), with the latter becoming later better known as [[Mother Teresa]]. Nikollë Bojaxhiu's company constructed the city's first theater and part of the railway line that connected Skopje with the region of Kosovo. He was also the owner of a wholesale food company and the only Roman Catholic member of the city council of Skopje.{{cite book|last=Alpion|first=Gëzim|title=Mother Teresa: Saint or Celebrity?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u_FE30FTbg0C|accessdate=19 October 2012|date=2006-12-26|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9780415392464|pages=148–51, 157–8}} On the day of the [[Albanian Declaration of Independence]] (November 28, 1912) he hosted a meeting that was attended by [[Bajram Curri]] and [[Hasan Prishtina]] among others. After the region's incorporation into Serbia, Bojaxhiu joined various Albanian rights political organizations. He died in 1919, a few hours after he returned from a political meeting in [[Belgrade]]. Several biographers have attributed his death to poisoning by Serbian agents. The location, purpose and participants of the meeting remain unknown. His son Lazar considered the theory of poisoning to be a certainty, while his daughter Agnes described it as unconfirmed. His funeral process was attended by large numbers of people and representative of all the religious communities. As a sign of respect, that day all school children were given dedicatory handkerchiefs and jewellers' shops remained closed. After his death, his partner appropriated the entirety of their companies' assets and left nothing to his widow and offspring. ==Ethnicity controversy== Nikollë Bojaxhiu was born into a [[Kosovar Albanian]] family.{{cite book|last=Poplin|first=Mary|title=The Marriage Devotional: 365 Simple Ways to Celebrate Your Love|date=28 January 2011|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=978-0830834723|page=97|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vzx3U2_cpogC&pg=PA97&dq=%22Mother+Teresa+Albanian%22#v=onepage&q=%22Mother%20Teresa%20Albanian%22&f=false|quote=Mother Teresa, Albanian Catholic Nun Founder of the missionaries of charity}}{{cite book|last=Group|first=Salisbury|title=The Salisbury Review, Volumes 19–20|date=28 January 2011|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=978-0830834723|page=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lf6BAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Mother+Teresa+Albanian%22&dq=%22Mother+Teresa+Albanian%22|quote=Mother Teresa, Albanian by birth}}{{cite news|title=Kosovo to Honor Mother Teresa|url=http://www.zenit.org/en/articles/kosovo-to-honor-mother-teresa|accessdate=15 November 2014|publisher=Zenit|date=6 March 2007}}{{cite news|title=Mother Teresa Beyond the Image|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/first/s/sebba-teresa.html|accessdate=15 November 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=1997}}{{cite book|last1=Alpion|first1=Gëzim|date=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|title=Mother Teresa: Saint or Celebrity? |isbn=0203087518|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rq6S6qCWCbUC&pg=PT266&lpg=PT266&dq=mother+teresa+kosovo+prizren#v=onepage&q=mother%20teresa%20kosovo%20prizren&f=false|accessdate=15 November 2014|quote="the nun's mother was born in Prizren in Kosova, her family came originally from the Gjakova region, also in Kosova"}} In 2003 Albanian scholar [[Wikipedia_talk:Articles_for_creation/Aurel_Plasari|Aurel Plasari]] claimed that Nikollë Bojaxhiu could have been of [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] origin, mainly based on a document, found by Macedonian author Stojan Trencevski, which asserted that Mr. Bojaxhiu was, at some point, the representative of the Aromanian community of Skopje.{{cite web|last=Plasari|first=Aurel|url=http://www.trepca.net/2003/1003/031013-ap-bojagjite.e.nene.terezes.htm|title=Bojaxhite e Nene Terezes|publisher=Shekulli|date=29 September 2003}} However this hypothesis has been rejected by scholar Albert Ramaj, who, based on the testimony of a contemporary, Lalush Lalevski, argues that the representative of the Aromanian community at the time, whose last name was Boiadjijev, was another person, and entirely unrelated to Nikollë Bojaxhiu.[http://www.trepca.net/2003/1103/031115-a.ramaj-reagim.ndaj.shk.a.plasarit-bojaxhite.e.nene.terezes.htm Ramaj, Albert in "Stublla 15 November 2003, p. 12] Ramaj's position was later endorsed by scholars Ukshini and Xhufi. {{cite journal | title = , ethnicity and patriotism—the Balkans ‘unholy war’ for the appropriation of Mother Teresa | journal = Journal of Southern Europe and the Balkans | date = December 2004 | first = Gëzim | last = Alpion | volume = 6 | issue = 3 | url = http://www.socscistaff.bham.ac.uk/gezim_alpion/downloads/Media_ethnicity_and_patriotism.pdf | accessdate = 2012-10-29}} Mother Teresa had said: “By blood, I am Albanian. By citizenship, an Indian. By faith, I am a Catholic nun. As to my calling, I belong to the world. As to my heart, I belong entirely to the heart of Jesus.”{{cite book|last1=Mazzuca|first1=Nate|last2=Noble|first2=Avery|title=Those Who Came Before Us|url=https://books.google.al/books?id=rtfsBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT244&dq=By+blood,+I+am+Albanian.+By+citizenship,+an+Indian.+By+faith,+I+am+a+Catholic+nun.+As+to+my+calling,+I+belong+to+the+world.+As+to+my+heart,+I+belong+entirely+to+the+heart+of+Jesus.%E2%80%9D&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj84pzY2_POAhUEaxQKHYYyD7kQ6AEIGDAA#v=onepage&q=By%20blood%2C%20I%20am%20Albanian.%20By%20citizenship%2C%20an%20Indian.%20By%20faith%2C%20I%20am%20a%20Catholic%20nun.%20As%20to%20my%20calling%2C%20I%20belong%20to%20the%20world.%20As%20to%20my%20heart%2C%20I%20belong%20entirely%20to%20the%20heart%20of%20Jesus.%E2%80%9D&f=false|page=244|publisher=Lulu.com}} == Sources == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bojaxhi, Nikolle}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:Kosovo Albanians]] [[Category:Albanian Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Kosovan Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Albanian businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century Albanian politicians]] [[Category:Local political office-holders in Albania]] [[Category:People from Prizren]]

revision.text:
'''PaperWorks''' was a [[computer program]] introduced by [[Xerox Corporation]] in 1992, which allowed a business traveler to [[communicate]] with his or her [[personal computer]] while away from the [[office]].
PaperWorks could be used to send and retrieve documents between the fixed computer system and the business traveler, by using [[fax]] machines.
The software created special [[Machine-readable data|machine-readable]] [[Form (document)|forms]], similar to the type of forms used to score [[standardized tests]]. (Related topic: [[Optical mark recognition|OMR]])
The [[user (computing)|user]] would then [[fax]] the form back to the central computer, commanding one of several tasks to be performed. For example: * the user could attach a document to the form which would be stored at the home office (for possible later processing), or * the user could request that a particular [[document]], stored on the computer's [[hard drive]], be sent to the user. * the user could request that a particular [[document]] be distributed to other users, also by fax.
The underlying technology for PaperWorks, called "[[DataGlyphs]]"[http://www.dataglyphs.com], was developed at [[Xerox PARC]].
==External links== * [https://archive.is/20040321071141/http://www.seyboldreports.com/SRDP/dp6/DP06-09.htm Seybold Report on Desktop Publishing, May 1992] * [http://catless.ncl.ac.uk/Risks/13.35.html#subj6 'The Risks Digest', April 1992] * [http://www.parc.xerox.com/about/history/default.html Xerox PARC Historical Timeline]
