revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = ParAccel, Inc. | logo = ParAccel-Logo-Oct2011.jpg | type = [[Subsidiary]] |parent= [[Actian]] | foundation = 2005 | location = [[Campbell, California|Campbell]] and [[San Diego]], [[California]] [[United States]] | industry = [[Data Warehousing]]
[[Enterprise Software]]
[[Database Management]]
[[Business Analytics]] | products = The ParAccel Analytic Platform
ParAccel Base / Advanced Analytic Packages
Informatica Adaptor for ParAccel | homepage = {{URL |www.actian.com}} }} '''ParAccel, Inc.''' was a [[California]]-based software company. It provided a [[database management system]] designed for advanced [[analytics]] for [[business intelligence]]. ParAccel was acquired by [[Actian]] in April 2013.{{Cite news |title= Actian Picks Up ParAccel to Boost Analytics Portfolio |work= Silicon Angle |date= April 29, 2013 |author= Maria Duetscher |url= http://siliconangle.com/blog/2013/04/29/actian-picks-up-paraccel-to-boost-analytics-portfolio/ |accessdate= November 19, 2013 }} ==History== ParAccel was a venture-backed company focused on developing software for data analysis. It acquired some [[intellectual property]] from the company XPrime, which ended operations in 2005.{{Cite news |title= Warehouse appliances: boom or bust? |work= The Register |date= December 13, 2005 |author= Philip Howard |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/12/13/warehouse_appliances/ |accessdate= January 20, 2014 }}{{Cite news |title= ParACCEL up and running: The new boy on the data warehouse appliance block |work= The Register |date= March 30, 2006 |author= Philip Howard |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/03/30/paraccel_enters_datawarehouse_market/ |accessdate= January 20, 2014 }} It was officially incorporated in February 2006, founded by Barry Zane who became chief technology officer, and was first funded by [[angel investor]]s. In August 2006 the first series of [[venture capital]] came from [[Mohr Davidow Ventures]], Bay Partners and Tao Venture Partners. In 2007 the company was based in [[San Diego, California]], with an office in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]]. David J. Ehrlich was chief executive, and Bruce Scott, vice president of engineering.{{Cite web |title= Company: Accelerating Business Intelligence |work= Old ParAccel web page |url= http://www.paraccel.com/company.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070820103518/http://www.paraccel.com/company.html |archivedate= August 20, 2007 |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} In November 2007, a second round of $20 million included previous investors and was led by Walden Ventures.{{Cite web |title= Notice of Sale of Securities [Regulation D and Section 4(6) of the Securities Act of 1933], item 06 |publisher= US Securities and Exchange Commission |date= November 28, 2007 |url= https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/vprr/07/9999999997-07-050041 |format= PDF |accessdate= November 19, 2013 }} In December the company opened an office in [[Cupertino, California]] (part of [[Silicon Valley]]).{{Cite news |title= ParAccel Secures $20 Million in Venture Financing and Opens Cupertino Office |date= December 10, 2007 |work= Press release |url= http://paraccel.com/pdf/ParAccel_Secures_Financing.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080517045326/http://paraccel.com/pdf/ParAccel_Secures_Financing.pdf |archivedate= May 17, 2008 |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} A third round of $22 million in June 2009 was led by [[Menlo Ventures]]. In January 2010 Mark Lockareff replaced Ehrlich as interim chief executive.{{Cite news |title=ParAccel Appoints Charles W. Berger as CEO |date= September 8, 2010 |work= Press release |url= http://paraccel.com/paraccel-appoints-charles-w-berger-as-ceo/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100912030026/http://paraccel.com/paraccel-appoints-charles-w-berger-as-ceo/ |archivedate= September 12, 2010 |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} In March 2010 the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' listed ParAccel in a list of venture backed companies that included [[Solyndra]].{{cite news |title= The Next Big Thing: The Top 50 Venture-Backed Companies |date= March 9, 2010 |url= http://graphicsweb.wsj.com/documents/NEXT_BIG_THING/NEXT_BIG_THING.html |work=The Wall Street Journal |archivedate= March 12, 2010 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100312000910/http://graphicsweb.wsj.com/documents/NEXT_BIG_THING/NEXT_BIG_THING.html |accessdate= October 25, 2016 }} A result from the TPC-H benchmark from the [[Transaction Processing Performance Council]] in April 2010 had record performance at 1 TB data size using [[VMware]].{{Cite news |title= ParAccel, VMware Break 1TB TPC-H Performance Record with World’s First Virtualized TPC-H |work= Press release |date= April 12, 2010 |url= http://paraccel.com/paraccel-vmware-break-1tb-tpc-h-performance-record-with-worlds-first-virtualized-tpc-h/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111024043314/http://paraccel.com/paraccel-vmware-break-1tb-tpc-h-performance-record-with-worlds-first-virtualized-tpc-h/ |archivedate= October 24, 2011 |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }}{{Cite web |title= VMware ESXi platform/HP DL380/ParAccel Analytic |work= TPC-H Result Highlight |date= April 11, 2010 |url= http://www.tpc.org/tpch/results/tpch_result_detail.asp?id=110041101 |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} Charles W. Berger was appointed chairman and CEO in September 2010. By early 2011 many of its competitors had been acquired.{{Cite web |title=Why ParAccel’s Time on the Big Data Singles Circuit Won’t Be Long |work= Giga Om |author= Derrick Harris |date= March 11, 2011 |url= http://gigaom.com/2011/03/11/why-paraccels-time-on-the-big-data-singles-circuit-wont-be-long/ |accessdate= November 21, 2013 }} During its July 2011 funding round, existing investors were led by [[Amazon.com]].{{Cite web |title= Amazon invests big in big data startup |work= Giga Om |author= Derrick Harris |date= July 7, 2011 |url= http://gigaom.com/2011/07/07/amazon-invests-big-in-big-data-startup/ |accessdate= November 21, 2013 }} In December 2012, the [[Amazon Redshift]] database service was announced (and generally available in early 2013) using ParAccel technology.{{Cite news |title= Amazon Redshift Leaves On-Premises Opening, Says ParAccel |date= December 6, 2012 |work= Information Week |author= Doug Henschen |url= http://www.informationweek.com/software/information-management/amazon-redshift-leaves-on-premises-opening-says-paraccel/d/d-id/1107684 |accessdate= November 19, 2013 }}{{Cite web |title=Watch out HP, IBM, Teradata, Oracle: Amazon Redshift is here |work= Giga Om |author= Barb Darrow |date= February 15, 2013 |url= http://gigaom.com/2013/02/15/watch-out-hp-ibm-teradata-oracle-amazon-redshift-is-here/ |accessdate= November 21, 2013 }} ParAccel was based in California with offices in [[Campbell, California|Campbell]] and [[San Diego]]. Competitors included [[Greenplum]] (from [[GoPivotal|Pivotal]]), [[EXASOL]], [[Vertica]] (from [[Hewlett-Packard]]), [[Netezza]] (from [[IBM]]), [[Oracle Corporation]], and [[Teradata]] (including its [[Aster Data Systems]] technology).{{Cite news |title= Comparing Vertica, ParAccel and Exasol |date= August 19, 2008 |work= Information Week |author= Curt Monash |url= http://www.informationweek.com/software/information-management/comparing-vertica-paraccel-and-exasol/d/d-id/1071118 |accessdate= November 19, 2013 }} ParAccel was acquired by [[Actian]] in April 2013.{{Cite news |title= Actian Acquires ParAccel, Fuel Behind Amazon RedShift |date= April 25, 2013 |work= Information Week |author= Doug Henschen |url= http://www.informationweek.com/software/information-management/actian-acquires-paraccel-fuel-behind-amazon-redshift/d/d-id/1109699 |accessdate= November 19, 2013 }} Berger left at that time to become CEO of [[Extreme Networks]].{{Cite news |title= Extreme Networks replaces its CEO again |work= Network World |date= April 25, 2013 |author= Jim Duffy |url= http://www.networkworld.com/news/2013/042513-extreme-ceo-269145.html |accessdate= December 6, 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131212190603/http://www.networkworld.com/news/2013/042513-extreme-ceo-269145.html |archivedate= December 12, 2013 |df= }} ==Products== In 2008 ParAccel offered two different products: Amigo and Maverick.{{Cite web |title= Getting to Know ParAccel, Part II |author= Thomas C. Briggs |date= February 25, 2008 |work= Full Table Scan blog |url= http://www.fulltablescan.com/index.php?/archives/71-Getting-to-Know-ParAccel,-Part-II.html |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} Amigo was designed to accelerate queries directed at an existing data warehouse while leaving the data warehouse as the database of record. In contrast Maverick was designed as a stand-alone data store.{{Cite web |title= ParAccel Corporate Brief |work= HP partner web site |date= March 4, 2009 |url= http://h21007.www2.hp.com/portal/download/partner/Corporate%20Brief%20on%20ParAccel%20Data%20Warehousing%20v6_1236198035276.pdf |accessdate= January 13, 2014 }} ParAccel discontinued Amigo in favor of the stand-alone offering which evolved into the ParAccel Analytic Database (PADB).{{When |date= January 2014}} The ParAccel Analytic Database was a parallel relational database system using a [[shared-nothing architecture]] with a columnar orientation, [[adaptive compression]], memory-centric design.{{Cite journal |title= Partial join order optimization in the paraccel analytic database |work= Proceedings of the 2009 ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of data |pages= 905–908 |authors= Yijou Chen, Richard L. Cole, William J. McKennal, Sergei Perfilov, Aman Sinha, Eugene Szedenits, Jr. |date= June 29, 2009 |doi= 10.1145/1559845.1559945 |isbn= 978-1-60558-551-2 }} ParAccel's DBMS engine is built for analytics, initially based on [[PostgreSQL]]. ParAccel began phasing in a new optimizer (Omne) in release 2.0 and made significant changes to Omne in subsequent releases (3.1 released in June 2011). ParAccel implements compiled queries, and a proprietary interconnect protocol for inter-node communications. It integrated with [[storage area network]] technologies such as those from [[EMC Corporation]].{{Cite web |title= ParAccel Update |author= Thomas C. Briggs |date= March 17, 2009 |work= Full Table Scan blog |url= http://www.fulltablescan.com/index.php?/archives/155-ParAccel-Update.html |accessdate= December 6, 2013 }} ParAccel offered on-demand integration (ODI) modules for analytics and data outside of the ParAccel Analytic Platform. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.paraccel.com/}} [[Category:Business intelligence]] [[Category:Data warehousing products]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]]

[[File:PinpointBPS-Orange-01.svg|alt=PinpointBPS|thumb|The PinpointBPS logo is used to represent the accredited use of the methodology in laboratories.]] '''PinpointBPS''' is a [[methodology]] for process improvement in laboratories.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.miningweekly.com/article/rbcts-new-coal-sampling-lab-designed-to-accommodate-expansion-provides-quality-assurance-2016-07-15/rep_id:3650|title=RBCT’s new coal sampling lab designed to accommodate expansion, provides quality assurance|last=Breytenbach|first=Mia|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> It is underpinned by eight principles that form the basis for decision-making in a laboratory.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinpointbps.com/principles|title=Principles|website=PinpointBPS® Movement {{!}} Optimizing laboratory performance using the 8 Principles of Certainty|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> While its application is mainly in healthcare — particularly [[Medical laboratory|medical laboratories]] — it has also been applied in other industries. The methodology has been heralded as "groundbreaking" in the field of laboratory performance improvement.<ref name=":0" />
== Overview == Medical laboratories operate in highly regulated environments that demand consistent quality of patient outputs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Parwani|first=Anil V.|last2=Hassell|first2=Lewis|last3=Glassy|first3=Eric|last4=Pantanowitz|first4=Liron|date=2014-10-21|title=Regulatory barriers surrounding the use of whole slide imaging in the United States of America|journal=Journal of Pathology Informatics|volume=5|doi=10.4103/2153-3539.143325|issn=2229-5089|pmc=4221881|pmid=25379344|pages=38}}</ref> The external environment’s impact on the broader global healthcare industry is also dictating the need for ongoing improvements in quality and delivery<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pathology|first=Association of Directors of Anatomic and Surgical|date=2006-09-01|title=Recommendations for Quality Assurance and Improvement in Surgical and Autopsy Pathology|url=http://ajcp.oxfordjournals.org/content/126/3/337|journal=American Journal of Clinical Pathology|language=en|volume=126|issue=3|pages=337–340|doi=10.1309/2TVBY2D8131FAMAX|issn=0002-9173|pmid=16880147}}</ref> while using fewer resources that leads to cost savings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-34589128|title=Lord Carter's plans for saving the NHS £5bn a year - BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> Among other regulations, the Carter Report in the [[United Kingdom]] dictates that GBP£200-million in cost savings must be achieved by 2020,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nhsemployers.org/news/2016/02/carter-report|title=Carter Report - NHS Employers|website=www.nhsemployers.org|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> while the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] in the [[United States]], also known as Obamacare, imposed further taxation requirements on medical laboratories, reducing cost saving ability.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlo-online.com/labs-speak-out-against-additional-affordable-care-act-cuts.php|title=Labs speak out against additional Affordable Care Act cuts {{!}} MLO|last=Allen|first=Julie Scott|website=www.mlo-online.com|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> Dr. Jonathan Berg stated at [[Royal College of Pathologists|The Royal College of Pathologists]]' annual meeting in 2012 that "We need to be creative and innovative in the services we offer, and we need to get our finances under control",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bivda.co.uk/News/PressReleases/tabid/73/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/710/jobs.aspx|title=Experts meet to explore the Value of Pathology ahead of the National Pathology Year 2012 > BIVDA - The British In Vitro Diagnostics Association > Member Press Releases|website=www.bivda.co.uk|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> indicating the critical need for innovation within pathology and a stronger focus on financial controls and performance. Within this context, PinpointBPS was founded as a methodology focusing on [[innovation]], [[risk management|risk reduction]] and financial impact<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinpointbps.com/news/2016/3/11/continuous-improvement-in-pathology-laboratories|title=Uncertainty: Is resistance to change inhibiting innovation in laboratories?|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> relating to laboratory performance improvement.
== Methodology == The PinpointBPS methodology is centered on the following process of discovery that highlights current performance, expected future performance and the means to achieve it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinpointbps.com/news/2016/3/10/pinpointbps-movement-continuous-improvement|title=Inside the PinpointBPS® Movement: Innovating Towards Certainty in Laboratories|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> The methodology has also been aligned with [[ISO 15189]] requirements.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinpointbps.com/news/2016/4/28/iso15189-guidelines|title=Taking care of ISO 15189 compliance with PinpointBPS®|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref>
=== The PinpointBPS Methodology === The steps below provide a high-level overview of the methodology in practice.
==== 1. Focus on quantified value ==== While all effort within the laboratory is put into value creation, from [[turnaround time]] improvements to quality output and cost savings / profit increases, it is important that the performance of each of these can be quantified and their relationship with the financial performance of the laboratory understood.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.darkdaily.com/creating-added-value-from-clinical-pathology-laboratory-testing-produced-improved-outcomes-at-university-of-mississippi-medical-center-and-broward-health622|title=Creating Added Value from Clinical Pathology Laboratory Testing Produced Improved Outcomes at University of Mississippi Medical Center and Broward Health {{!}} Dark Daily|website=www.darkdaily.com|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> This enables the laboratory to understand current performance needs while at the same time establishing the [[Performance indicator|key performance indicators]] that are important and should be measured.
==== 2. Determine current performance ==== Understanding the current performance of the laboratory provides the necessary context to highlight performance improvement requirements as well as areas of excellence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dana|first=Travnickova|date=2009|title=Processes assessment and monitoring in a clinical laboratory|url=http://qip-journal.eu/files/2009/2009-1/QIP_1-2009_Travnickova.pdf|journal=Quality Innovation Prosperity|volume=8|issue=1|access-date=July 20, 2016}}</ref> This should be conducted by looking at sample turnaround time and resource utilization, and should be considered on a holistic basis, creating a virtual model of the whole laboratory by mapping out all processes and activities in detail. This provides an end-to-end perspective on current performance and forms the basis for future performance improvement initiatives.
==== 3. Understand future performance ==== The expectation for future performance should be done through [[business process modeling]], with current performance as the foundation. Using LIS data as well as data from workforce scheduling, and combining this data with the process model of the laboratory, creates an environment where changes to the laboratory can be [[Simulation|simulated]] and the impact to performance understood in quantifiable terms. It is important to validate both the integrity of the [[data]] and the accuracy of the model.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ezzelle|first=J.|last2=Rodriguez-Chavez|first2=I. R.|last3=Darden|first3=J. M.|last4=Stirewalt|first4=M.|last5=Kunwar|first5=N.|last6=Hitchcock|first6=R.|last7=Walter|first7=T.|last8=D’Souza|first8=M. P.|date=2008-01-07|title=Guidelines on Good Clinical Laboratory Practice|journal=Journal of pharmaceutical and biomedical analysis|volume=46|issue=1|pages=18–29|doi=10.1016/j.jpba.2007.10.010|issn=0731-7085|pmc=2213906|pmid=18037599}}</ref> Once a desirable outcome for future performance has been found, the difference (or delta) in performance is evaluated to understand future performance requirements.
==== 4. Establish performance delta and requirements ==== The difference in performance between current ([[Baseline (budgeting)|baseline]]) and future (expected) performance highlights the necessary process changes and related initiatives that are required to achieve the future performance. This impact should be measured according to finance ([[cost]] or [[Profit (accounting)|profit]]), quality and turnaround time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hawkins|first=Robert C|date=2007-11-01|title=Laboratory Turnaround Time|journal=The Clinical Biochemist Reviews|volume=28|issue=4|pages=179–194|issn=0159-8090|pmc=2282400|pmid=18392122}}</ref> For these changes to take effect, each change initiative is prioritized based on a quantified understanding of its impact to the laboratory 'bottom line', while also improving turnaround time, quality or both.
=== Comparison with Lean === While the PinpointBPS methodology can support [[Lean manufacturing|Lean]] (and other [[Continual improvement process|continuous improvement]] methodologies like [[Six Sigma]]) in that it ultimately aims to provide patients and other stakeholders with quality outputs, its approach differs from other methodologies like the [[Lean laboratory|Lean Laboratory]] in various ways: * While lean focuses on waste and the elimination thereof,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://businesscasestudies.co.uk/nestle/achieving-sustainability-through-lean-production/eliminating-waste.html|title=Eliminating waste - Achieving sustainability through lean production - Nestlé {{!}} Nestlé case studies, videos, social media and information {{!}} Business Case Studies|website=businesscasestudies.co.uk|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> PinpointBPS focuses on understanding process and the impact of changes to processes on value while reducing risk. * The definition of success differs in its layers of ambiguity. The focus of lean is to achieve "the happy situation of perfect value provided with zero waste",<ref>{{Cite book|title=Improving Health Management through Clinical Decision Support Systems|last=Moon|first=Jane D.|publisher=IGI Global|year=2016|isbn=9781466694323|location=Australia|pages=167}}</ref> while PinpointBPS aims to establish a quantified definition of future value — "facts and figures, no fluff".<ref name=":1" /> * Lean has evolved from the manufacturing approach first designed by [[Toyota]] in the 1950s,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lean.org/WhatsLean/History.cfm|title=A Brief History of Lean|website=www.lean.org|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref> while PinpointBPS has been specifically developed for use in [[pathology]] performance improvement. * Lean allows for the focus and treatment of individual or isolated performance issues,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McCulloch|first=Peter|last2=Kreckler|first2=Simon|last3=New|first3=Steve|last4=Sheena|first4=Yezen|last5=Handa|first5=Ashok|last6=Catchpole|first6=Ken|date=2010-01-01|title=Effect of a "Lean" intervention to improve safety processes and outcomes on a surgical emergency unit|journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.)|volume=341|pages=c5469|issn=1756-1833|pmid=21045024|doi=10.1136/bmj.c5469}}</ref> while PinpointBPS motivates for a system-wide approach first by creating visibility and testing. * Prioritization in Lean is done according customer priority or on a [[FIFO and LIFO accounting|FIFO]] (first in, first out) basis, while PinpointBPS encourages prioritization according to expected, quantified output linked to cost reduction or profit generation.
== PinpointBPS in Practice == PinpointPBS has been based on eight practical principles that allow laboratories to take ownership of the methodology and performance improvement initiatives.<ref name=":1" />
=== The 8 Principles ===
==== 1. Boost the bottom-line, or bust ==== As with any organization, value creation is the ultimate goal, however purely focusing on quality output may neglect cognizance of financial value. Understanding the ultimate financial impact of any value creating activity is critical for ongoing [[sustainability]].
==== 2. Led by a common language ==== Ensuring that everyone in the [[organization]] (and [[value chain]]) has the same understanding of value creation and how it links to financial performance
Continuous innovation requires us to draw from the same knowledge and speak the same language. We establish a [[Universal Truths and Cycles|universal truth]] that enables us to work together seamlessly.
==== 3. Trust the transparency ==== We value a clear line of sight into our strengths, our weaknesses and the connections between every process, person, and piece of technology.
==== 4. Facts and figures, no fluff ==== We believe in making decisions based on evidence. In our quest for bottom-line impact, every business action must be supported by real, tangible proof.
==== 5. Driven by decisiveness ==== We are empowered through understanding our performance and what shapes it. This allows everyone in our organization to make decisions swiftly, with understanding and certainty.
==== 6. Inaccuracy is inexcusable ==== Close is not close enough. Every decision we take is based on fact, and our execution must be accomplished with the same precision
==== 7. Big impact beats small ==== We believe in following the big opportunities that significantly impact the bottom line, rather than wasting time and resources on those that do not.
==== 8. Knowledge knows no bounds ==== We are only as good as the collective we represent. We fundamentally believe in continually imparting [[knowledge]] and learning from each other to move the industry forward.
== Tools == Various tools have been developed to enable the methodology in laboratories, including performance overviews, standardized process mapping using [[Business Process Model and Notation|BPMN]] (business process model and notation), as well as simulation and [[Scenario planning|scenario modeling]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinpointbps.com/solutions|title=Solutions|website=PinpointBPS® Movement {{!}} Optimizing laboratory performance using the 8 Principles of Certainty|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref>
== Professional certification == PinpointBPS professional [[certification]] can be granted to both laboratories that practice the methodology, as well as people who have successfully completed further study of the methodology. Two levels of PinpointBPS professional certifications exist. These certifications have been [[Accreditation|accredited]] by [http://www.ascls.org/p-a-c-e PACE], [https://cpduk.co.uk/ CPD], and the [https://www.rcpath.org/ Royal College of Pathologists].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ltsconsulting.com/learning|title=LTS Learning - Training courses for diagnostics laboratories|website=LTS Holdings|access-date=2016-07-20}}</ref>
=== Champion === A PinpointBPS Champion is a professional who is able to interpret laboratory performance improvement metrics, map out all processes within a laboratory and make improvement recommendations.
=== Master === A PinpointBPS Master builds on the PinpointBPS Champion certification and is a professional who is able to simulate changes to a laboratory and interpret performance outputs, to make performance improvement recommendations and manage initiatives from start to end.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Laboratories]] [[Category:Business process]]

revision.comment: /* Liquor Bottle Sizes */ Added US liquor bottle size and history
revision.text:
'''Preferred metric sizes''' are a set of [[international standard]]s and [[de facto standard]]s that are designed to make using the metric system easier and simpler, especially in engineering and construction practices. One of the methods used to arrive at these preferred sizes is the use of [[Preferred number|preferred numbers]] and [[Convenient number|convenient numbers]] such as the [[Renard series]], the [[1-2-5 series]] to limit the number of different sizes of components needed.
One of the largest benefits of such limits is an ensuing multiplicative or exponential reduction in the number of parts, tools and other items needed to support the installation and maintenance of the items built using these techniques. This occurs because eliminating one diameter fastener will typically allow the elimination of a large number of variations on that diameter (multiple thread pitches, multiple lengths, multiple tip types, multiple head types, multiple drive types, and the tools needed for installing each, including multiple drill bits (one for each different thread pitch, material, and fit combination).
== Food & Beverages == === Liquor Bottle Sizes === International agreements, including 75/106/EEC,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.welmec.org/fileadmin/user_files/publications/6-1.pdf|title=Application of Directives 75/106/EEC and 76/211/EEC concerning the marking and quantity control of e-marked prepackages|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-17}}</ref> specify 0.1, 0.25 ({{frac|1|4}}), 0.375 ({{frac|3|8}}), 0.5 ({{frac|1|2}}), 0.75 ({{frac|3|4}}), 1, 1.5, 2, 3, and 5 litres as the capacities of liquor bottles allowed in international commerce.
In the United States, the alcohol industry switched to metric bottle sizes on October 1, 1976, abandoning the existing 38 sizes of bottles and instead adopting the following sizes:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/10/11/archives/liquor-industry-converts-to-metric-system-liquor-industry-is.html|title=Liquor Industry Converts to Metric System|last=Cherry|first=Rona|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en}}</ref>
* 50 ml (miniature) * 200 ml (replaced the half-pint) * 500 ml (replaced the pint) * 750 ml (replaced the fifth) * 1000 ml (replaced the quart) * 1750 ml (replaced the half-gallon)
== Building Construction == See Also: * [[#ISO 6708 Nominal Diameter|ISO 6708 Nominal Diameter]] (for garden hose sizes)
=== System 32 Furniture === [[System 32 (furniture)|System 32]] is a standard for the design and manufacture of furniture, most commonly used in the design of cabinets, wherein the major parts (sides, doors, etc.) are available in increments of 32 mm, and shelf supports consist of columns of 5 mm holes on 32 mm centers.
=== ISO 2848 Basic Module === The [[ISO 2848]] basic module is a unit of 100 mm, often represented by a single capital "M", along with 300 mm and 600 mm groupings, that is widely used for the widths of furniture in Europe. * A standard metric (concrete) block is 190 mm wide, 390 mm long, and 190 mm high, which allows for 10 mm mortar joints in between bricks, giving a standard unit size of 200 mm square by 400 mm long.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://themetricmaven.com/?p=8268|title=Another Brick in the Wall|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * A standard metric brick is 90 by 57 by 190 mm; with 10 mm of mortar, that produces a standard unit of 100 mm x 200 mm.<ref name=":0" />
== Office Equipment & Supplies == === ISO 216 Paper Sizes === [[ISO 216]] standard specifies the A sizes of paper, including the very common A4, wherein the base size of A0 is one square meter, and the ratio between the height and width is {{radic|2}}, which results in all sizes of paper having the same aspect ratio.
Also related is the set of pen thicknesses for technical drawings (0.13, 0.18, 0.25, 0.35, 0.50, 0.70, 1.00, 1.40, and 2.00 mm).
== Manufacturing == === ISO 261 and 262 Fastener Diameters === ISO 261 defines a set of preferred metric machine screw/bolt sizes, and [[ISO 262]] defines a subset of those; both are based roughly on [[Renard series]] as defined in [[ISO 3]], [[ISO 17]], and [[ISO 497]]. Given that even ISO 262 specifies a fairly large set of diameters, a much simplified set of preferred diameters was developed by one of the lead designers of [[ASME Z17.1]] and ANSI B4.2, Knut O. Kverneland,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Metric Standards for Worldwide Manufacturing|last=Kverneland|first=Knut O.|publisher=Amer Society of Mechanical Engineers|year=1996|isbn=978-0791800416|location=|pages=}}</ref> to reduce the list to 6 preferred sizes, and another 6 intermediate supplementary sizes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gometricusa.org/table2.html|title=TABLE 2 - FASTENER SIZES|last=Kverneland|first=Kurt|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-17}}</ref>
For each size bolt or screw and type of head, there is a corresponding size driver prescribed by various ISO standards, including: * Internal hex drive: ISO 2936:2001 "Assembly tools for screws and nuts—Hexagon socket screw keys" * External hex drive: ISO 4014, 4015, 4015, 4017, and 4018. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |ISO 262 sizes | colspan="5" |'''Hex driver and wrench sizes''' |- !1st choice R<nowiki>''</nowiki>5 !2nd choice R'10 !Internal hex, cap head !Internal hex, button head !Internal hex, flat head screws !Internal hex, set screws !External hex, ISO standard |- |'''M2.5''' | |'''2.0 mm''' | | |'''2.0 mm''' | |- | |M3 |2.5 mm |2.0 mm |2.0 mm |2.0 mm | |- |'''M4''' | |'''3.0 mm''' |'''2.5 mm''' |'''2.5 mm''' |'''2.5 mm''' |'''7 mm''' |- | |M5 |4.0 mm |3.0 mm |3.0 mm |3.0 mm | |- |'''M6''' | |'''5.0 mm''' |'''4.0 mm''' |'''4.0 mm''' |'''3.5 mm''' |'''10 mm''' |- | |M8 |6.0 mm |5.0 mm |5.0 mm |5.0 mm | |- |'''M10''' | |'''8.0 mm''' |'''6.0 mm''' |'''6.0 mm''' |'''6.0 mm''' |'''16 mm''' |- | |M12 |10.0 mm |8.0 mm |8.0 mm |8.0 mm | |- |'''M16''' | |'''14.0 mm''' | |'''10.0 mm''' |'''10.0 mm''' |'''24 mm''' |- | |M20 |17.0 mm | |12.0 mm |12.0 mm | |- |'''M24''' | |'''19.0 mm''' | | | |'''36 mm''' |- | |M30 | | | | | |} For each size bolt or screw and type of head, there is a corresponding size driver prescribed by Acument, the designer of the Torx drive system. {{As of|2018}}, there are no ISO standards for hexalobular drive sizes. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |ISO 262 sizes | colspan="5" |'''Torx driver and wrench sizes'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acument.com/pdfs/torx_ds.pdf|title=Torx Drive System|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> | |- !1st choice R<nowiki>''</nowiki>5 !2nd choice R'10 !Pan head !Flat head !Socket head !Socket Button !Truss !External Torx |- |'''M2.5''' | |'''T8''' |'''T8''' |'''T8''' | | | |- | |M3 |T10 |T10 |T10 |T8 | |E4 |- |'''M4''' | |'''T20''' |'''T20''' |'''T25''' |'''T15''' |'''T15''' |'''E5''' |- | |M5 |T25 |T25 |T27 |T25 |T20 |E6 |- |'''M6''' | |'''T30''' |'''T30''' |'''T30''' |'''T27''' |'''T30''' |'''E8''' |- | |M8 |T40 |T40 |T45 |T40 |T40 |E10 |- |'''M10''' | |'''T50''' |'''T50''' |'''T50''' |'''T45''' |'''T50''' |'''E12''' |- | |M12 | | |T55 |T55 |T55 |E14 |- |'''M16''' | | | |'''T70''' |'''T60''' | |'''E20''' |- | |M20 | | |T90 | | |E24 |- |'''M24''' | | | |'''T100''' | | |'''E32''' |- | |M30 | | | | | |E36 |} For each size bolt or screw and type of head, there is a corresponding size driver prescribed by Acument, the designer of the Torx Plus drive system. {{As of|2018}}, there are no ISO standards for hexalobular drive sizes.
{| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |ISO 262 sizes | colspan="5" |'''Torx Plus driver and wrench sizes'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stanleyengineeredfastening.com/sites/www.emhartamericas.com/files/downloads/Torx_Plus_Brochure_EN.pdf|title=Torx Plus Drive System|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> | |- !1st choice R<nowiki>''</nowiki>5 !2nd choice R'10 !Pan head !Flat head !Socket head !Socket Button !Truss !External Torx |- |'''M2.5''' | |'''8IP''' |'''8IP''' |'''8IP''' | | |'''4EP''' |- | |M3 |10IP |10IP |10IP |8IP | |5EP |- |'''M4''' | |'''20IP''' |'''15IP''' |'''20IP''' |'''15IP''' |'''15IP''' |'''7EP''' |- | |M5 |25IP |20IP |27IP |25IP |20IP |8EP |- |'''M6''' | |'''30IP''' |'''27IP''' |'''30IP''' |'''27IP''' |'''30IP''' |'''10EP''' |- | |M8 |45IP |30IP |45IP |40IP |40IP |14EP |- |'''M10''' | |'''50IP''' |'''50IP''' |'''50IP''' |'''45IP''' |'''50IP''' |'''16EP''' |- | |M12 |55IP |55IP |55IP |55IP |55IP |20EP |- |'''M16''' | | | |'''70IP''' |'''60IP''' | |'''26EP''' |- | |M20 | | |90IP | | |32EP |- |'''M24''' | | | |'''100IP''' | | |'''40EP''' |- | |M30 | | | | | | |} If using just the 1st choice bolt sizes, the list of drivers and wrenches needed for all hex and Torx sizes are:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acument.com/pdfs/torx_ds.pdf|title=Torx Drive System|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |+ !Allen key !Torx !Torx Plus !Hex wrench !External Torx !External Torx Plus |- |2 mm |T8 |8IP |5 mm |E5 |4EP |- |2.5 mm |T15 |15IP |7 mm |E8 |7EP |- |3 mm |T20 |20IP |10 mm |E12 |10EP |- |3.5 mm |T25 |27IP |16 mm |E20 |16EP |- |4 mm |T27 |30IP |24 mm |E32 |26EP |- |5 mm |T30 |45IP |36 mm | |40EP |- |6 mm |T45 |50IP | | | |- |8 mm |T50 |60IP | | | |- |10 mm |T60 |70IP | | | |- |14 mm |T70 |100IP | | | |- |19 mm |T100 | | | | |}
=== ISO 1307 Plastic Hose Sizes === ISO 1307:2006, Rubber and plastics hoses—Hose sizes, minimum and maximum inside diameters, and tolerances on cut-to-length hoses specifies nominal diameters for four different types of plastic hoses, including "Type C", which includes the typical [[garden hose]]. Each nominal diameter specifies different ID minimum and maximum values. Notice that the nominal size is a Renard Series. {| class="wikitable" !Nominal Size ID ! colspan="2" |Type C Non-mandrel-built
ID range !Inch equivalent
ID |- ! !min !max ! |- |3.2 |n/a |n/a | |- |4 |3.4 |4.6 | |- |5 |4.2 |5.4 | |- |6.3 |5.6 |7.2 |{{frac|1|8}} in |- |8 |7.2 |8.8 |{{frac|1|4}} in |- |10 |8.7 |10.3 |{{frac|3|8}} in |- |12.5 |11.9 |13.5 |{{frac|1|2}} in |- |16 |15.1 |16.7 |{{frac|5|8}} in |- |19 |18.3 |19.9 |{{frac|3|4}} in |- |20 |19.3 |20.9 | |- |25 |24.2 |26.6 |1 in |- |31.5 |30.2 |33.4 |{{frac|1|1|4}} in |- |38 |36.5 |39.7 |{{frac|1|1|2}} in |}
=== ISO 6708 Nominal Diameter === {{Anchor|ISO 6708}} Nominal diameter, abbreviated DN, is the designation system specified by ISO 6708 for specifying the diameter of trade sizes of metric pipework components, and is the metric equivalent to [[Nominal Pipe Size]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/21274.html|title=ISO 6708:1995: Pipework components -- Definition and selection of DN (nominal size)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> It is among several ISO specifications that formalize [[preferred number]]<nowiki/>s, and is referred to by numerous other international standards, including ISO 7598 and EN 10255. The complete set of DN values allowed by the standard are: {| class="wikitable" !DN designation !DN designation !DN designation |- |DN 10 |DN 250 |DN 1 500 |- |DN 15 |DN 300 |DN 1 600 |- |DN 20 |DN 350 |DN 1 800 |- |DN 25 |DN 400 |DN 2 000 |- |DN 32 |DN 450 |DN 2 200 |- |DN 40 |DN 500 |DN 2 400 |- |DN 50 |DN 600 |DN 2 600 |- |DN 60 |DN 700 |DN 2 800 |- |DN 65 |DN 800 |DN 3000 |- |DN 80 |DN 900 |DN 3200 |- |DN 100 |DN 1 000 |DN 3 400 |- |DN 125 |DN 1 100 |DN 3 600 |- |DN 150 |DN 1 200 |DN 3 800 |- |DN 200 |DN 1 400 |DN 4 000 |} The number following the DN is a [[Real versus nominal value|nominal value]] that is roughly the number of millimeters of a circular feature on the connection point of the pipe, fitting, coupling, etc., but often differing by a noticeable amount. If the DN value is related to the internal bore diameter of the feature, the size should be represented by DN/ID (for Inside Diameter), and if the DN value is related to the outside diameter, the size should be represented by DN/OD (for Outside Diameter).
The relationship between DN and [[Nominal Pipe Size|NPS]] pipe sizes are as follows. Note that the actual internal diameter varies depending on the pipe wall thickness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wes.ir/files/797832605piptub.pdf|title=Tube Sizes - ISO|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" !DN !Actual OD !NPS<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/31327.html|title=ISO 17292:2004, Metal ball valves for petroleum, petrochemical and allied industries|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref> |- !dimensionless !mm !dimensionless |- |DN 10 |17.2 |{{Frac|3|8}} |- |DN 15 |21.3 |{{Frac|1|2}} |- |DN 20 |26.9 |{{Frac|3|4}} |- |DN 25 |33.7 |1 |- |DN 32 |42.4 |{{Frac|1|1|4}} |- |DN 40 |48.3 |{{Frac|1|1|2}} |- |DN 50 |60.3 |2 |- |DN 65 |76.1 |{{Frac|2|1|2}} |- |DN 80 |88.9 |3 |- |DN 100 |114.3 |4 |- |DN 125 |139.7 | - |- |DN 150 |168.3 |6 |- |DN 200 |219.1 |8 |- |DN 250 |273 |10 |- |DN 300 |323.9 |12 |- |DN 350 |355.6 |14 |- |DN 400 |406.4 |16 |- |DN 450 |457 |18 |- |DN 500 |508 |20 |- |DN 600 |610 |24 |- |DN 700 |711 |28 |- |DN 750 |762 |32 |- |DN 800 |813 |34 |- |DN 900 |914 |36 |- |DN 1 000 |1016 |40 |- |DN 1 200 |1220 |48 |}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{unreliable sources|date=October 2011}} {{primary sources|date=October 2011}} {{one source|date=October 2011}} {{original research|date=October 2011}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Reed & Reed | logo = Reed-reed logo.jpg | type = Private | foundation = 1928 | location = [[Woolwich, Maine]],
United States | industry = [[Construction]] | products = Bridges, buildings, wind power, parking garages | homepage = [http://www.reed-reed.com/ www.reed-reed.com] | revenue = | operating income = | net income = }} '''Reed & Reed Inc.''' is a private general contractor based in [[Woolwich, Maine]]. ==Company history== Founded in 1928 by Captain [[Josiah W. Reed]] and son [[Carlton Day Reed]], the initial capital was roughly $2,000. By 1930, Reed & Reed was already beginning its first bridge construction projects. These would come to define the company's image for nearly five decades. Although founded in 1928, Reed & Reed, Inc. was first incorporated in 1982. Since then, operations have continued to grow and expand. In 1992, RR Caribbean Inc. was established in [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]] to handle the company's Caribbean ambitions. Only two years later, in 1994, the company purchased Callahan Brothers, Inc., a leading competitor in contracting and design. Perhaps the company's most high-profile project began in 2003 as a joint venture with rival Cianboro Inc. The [[Penobscot Narrows Bridge and Observatory]], which has become a [[Maine]] landmark, began construction following a competitive bid among many contractors. Other high-profile undertakings included one of New England's largest wind farms, located in [[Mars Hill, Maine]], and the new Ocean Gateway pier for cruise ships in [[Portland, Maine]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2011/09/15/pier-without-peer-in-maine_2011-09-15/|title=Pier without peer in Maine|date=2011-09-15|work=Press Herald|access-date=2018-02-01|language=en-US}} ==Expansion== While many of Reed & Reed's projects are located in Maine, job sites are scattered all over [[New England]] and the [[Caribbean]]. Although the bridge contracts continue to provide millions in revenue for the company every year, it has recently begun pursuing wind energy as a major initiative. As part of this, the corporate logo, as seen on their website, has added wind mills. The three main goals of Reed & Reed are clearly outlined: safety, quality, and performance. Often used by the State of Maine's [[Department of Transportation]] for large- and small-scale projects, Reed & Reed has built a reputation for quality throughout New England. In 2017 Reed & Reed purchased PLC Construction, an electrical transmission contractor, based out of New Hampshire.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pressherald.com/2017/04/17/maine-construction-firm-reed-reed-buys-new-hampshire-subcontractor/|title=Maine construction firm Reed & Reed buys New Hampshire subcontractor|date=2017-04-17|work=Press Herald|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}} PLC Construction was often a subcontractor of Reed & Reed and employed approximately 40 workers at the time of purchase. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.reed-reed.com/ Reed & Reed] — official web site * [https://reed-reed.com/projects/ List of projects] {{DEFAULTSORT:Reed and Reed}} [[Category:Construction and civil engineering companies of the United States]] [[Category:Sagadahoc County, Maine]] [[Category:Companies based in Maine]] [[Category:Construction industry]] [[Category:Privately held companies of the United States]]

revision.comment: /* Wimbledon */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Sam Hammam | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Samir Georges Nassib Hammam | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1947|7|17|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Sam Hammam|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/SAM+HAMMAM.-a0119885514|publisher=South Wales Echo|accessdate=7 January 2015|date=28 July 2004}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Shweir]], [[Lebanon]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|df=yes|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Lebanese | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = Football club chairman }} '''Samir "Sam" Hammam''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: سمير همام) is a Lebanese businessman, well known for his high-profile involvement in British [[association football|football]] clubs, and presently holding a life presidency at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23439428.stm "Sam Hammam urges Cardiff FC fans to back Vincent Tan"][[BBC]]Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref>
==Wimbledon== Originally moving to the area due to being a keen [[tennis]] fan, Hammam became involved in football by buying £40,000 worth of shares at [[Non-League football|non-league]] [[Wimbledon F.C.]] in two years,<ref>[http://football.guardian.co.uk/FA_Cup/Story/0,,629335,00.html "The Guardian: Still crazy"]</ref> eventually taking full control of the club in 1977.<ref name=inside>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sport/football/656552.stm|title=Hammam sells Wimbledon stake|date=25 February 2000|accessdate=5 January 2015|work=BBC}}</ref>
Under Hammam, Wimbledon achieved four promotions in nine years, becoming a [[Football League First Division]] club in 1986 and winning the [[FA Cup]] in [[1987–88 FA Cup|1988]].
In 1990, before Wimbledon had moved out of their [[Plough Lane]] ground to groundshare at [[Selhurst Park]] with local rivals [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], Hammam bought out a covenant held on the ground by the [[London Borough of Merton|Council]] that required it to be retained for sporting use.<ref>[http://www.wisa.org.uk/cgi/l/articles/index.cgi?action=show&id=523 "WISA article on lifting of Plough Lane covenant"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426070543/http://www.wisa.org.uk/cgi/l/articles/index.cgi?action=show&id=523 |date=26 April 2012 }} Retrieved on 23 December 2011.</ref> During the 1990s, Hammam failed in an attempt to relocate the club to [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/championship/3010879/Inside-Sport-Hammam-cast-in-villains-role-as-Dons-seek-happy-ending.html|title=Inside Sport: Hammam cast in villain's role as Dons seek happy ending|date=16 August 2001|accessdate=5 January 2015|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
In 1997, Hammam sold 80% of his shares in Wimbledon to [[Bjørn Rune Gjelsten]] and [[Kjell Inge Røkke]]. He sold the remaining 20% to Gjelsten and Røkke in February 2000, three months before the club's relegation from the [[Premier League]].<ref name=inside/> In 2004, Wimbledon F.C. was relocated to [[Milton Keynes]] and rebranded as the [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|MK Dons]], with the newly formed [[AFC Wimbledon]] often considered the successor club to the original Wimbledon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/9223993.stm|title=AFC Wimbledon chase FA Cup history against Stevenage |date=25 November 2010|accessdate=5 January 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>
==Cardiff City== Hammam purchased control of Cardiff City F.C. at the end of 2000, where he picked up where he left off with Wimbledon. After taking over at Cardiff, Hammam controversially pledged to get the entire Welsh nation to support Cardiff by renaming the club ''"The Cardiff Celts"'' and changing the club colours to green, red and white.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/846497.stm BBC Wales: Hammam: 'I will die for Cardiff Celts']</ref><sup>,</sup><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/863572.stm BBC Wales: Fans are Hammam's big worry]</ref>
At Cardiff he became a [[cult following|cult]]-hero with fans for taking part in their head-patting '[[The Ayatollah (football celebration)|do the Ayatollah]]' chant. One such game saw him performing the celebration during an infamous 2–1 home win in the [[FA Cup]] against then-[[Premier League]] side [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in 2002. This, along with other aspects of his behaviour during the match, was blamed for contributing to the subsequent violence between Leeds and Cardiff fans at the end of the match.<ref>[http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/sport/Cardiff-supremo-rejects-mayhem-claims.2292427.jp "Cardiff supremo rejects mayham claims"], ''[[The Scotsman]]'' Retrieved on 6 December 2008</ref>
After failing to get the new stadium plans agreed by [[Cardiff Council]] due to concerns over financial security in 2006, Hammam agreed to a takeover by a consortium led by new chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] and including local businessman Paul Guy. In March 2008, Cardiff City began a court case against financial backers Langston over the repayment of a loan believed to be worth around £31 million. During the hearing the barrister representing the club named Sam Hammam as the man they believe to be behind the company.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7290681.stm "Hammam named in Cardiff loan case"] [[BBC]] Retrieved on 14 March 2008,</ref> No settlement was reached in the case.
In July 2013, following Cardiff City's promotion to the Premier League, it emerged that Malaysian businessman [[Vincent Tan]], who had taken effective control of the club in 2010, was in advanced talks with Hammam – confirmed as Langston's spokesman – about repayment of the loan, then thought to be around £24 million.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23362625.stm "Vincent Tan: Cardiff City could be debt-free in 'days'"] [[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref> Four days later, on 18 July 2013, Tan announced that an "amicable resolution" had been reached between Cardiff City and Langston over the debt issue, with Sam Hammam becoming a life president of the club.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23413324.stm "Cardiff City: Tan & Langston reach "amicable resolution""]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref> Hammam confirmed this in an interview with the [[BBC]] on 24 July, requesting that fans of the club back the Malaysian owner.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-23439428.stm "Sam Hammam urges Cardiff FC fans to back Vincent Tan"][[BBC]] Retrieved on 17 August 2013,</ref>
==Controversy== Hammam has achieved a level of notoriety in English football for his unusual antics at matches, frequently walking around the pitchside during games, and his eccentric methods of publicising himself and his players. On at least one occasion he made a player eat sheep's testicles prior to signing with Cardiff City.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/1411563.stm BBC Sport:Prior moves to Cardiff 28 June 2001</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{succession box | title=[[Cardiff City F.C.]] chairman | before= [[Steve Borley]] | after= [[Peter Ridsdale]]| years=2000–2006}} {{s-end}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2017}} A '''superbill''' is an itemized form used by [[healthcare provider]]s for reflecting rendered services. Superbill is the main data source for creation of healthcare claim, which will be submitted to payers (insurances, funds, programs) for reimbursement. Although the superbill form is not unified, and it is created/modified depending on [[healthcare provider]] specialty, type of rendered services, additional requirements, as well as ease of handling, there is a set of obligatory attributes, relevant to all superbill types.
Superbill form consists of four main parts, containing mandatory fields to be completed for accurate claim creation:
==Provider information==
===Rendering provider===D'Alonzo, Shanon; Psychiachtric MD practicing physician, *Last/First name and Degree *Service location Allina clinic of Northfield MN mental health clinic *Signature
===Ordering/referring/attending physician=== *Last/First name and Degree *NPI ([[National Provider Identifier]]) *'''Referring provider NPI should not be blanked.'''
==Patient information== *Patient’s first and last name Robin Larson *Patient [[Date of birth|DOB]]03/28/1963 *Insurance Blue cross blue shield of mn /and ID) *Date of first symptom Spring 1981 worsened through 1982 college spring break *Last date seen (upon necessity)Dr D'Alonzo June 2018
==Visit information== *Date of service *[[Procedure codes]] (CPT) – list of commonly used codes by medical provider according to the provider specialty *[[Diagnosis codes]] ([[ICD-10]]) – list of commonly used codes by medical provider according to the provider specialty *Modifiers (Location and conditions modifiers) *Time (for timed codes) *Units *Quantity for drugs *Authorization information (if applicable)
==Additional information== *Notes and comments (for e.g.: PT cap)
==Superbill utilization rules== # Some insurance companies require a provider signature, while others will process billing without a signature{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} # All required fields should be completed (with the exception of those that are considered optional) # Provided information should be readable # CPT and ICD-10 codes should be marked clearly # In case if required CPT or ICD-10 code could not be found in the given list, Provider should give legible handwritten description of service/diagnosis, along with additional information (units, time, type, etc.) # Only generally accepted medical terminology and abbreviations are allowed {{citation needed|date=December 2017}}
==Further reading== * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/18145587/The-SuperbillGuide-to-a-Uniform-Billing-andOr-Claims-SystemIsBN-0685033295 ''The Superbill-Guide to a Uniform Billing and-Or Claims System]({{ISBN|0685033295}})by Medical Group Management Association Staff, Costello, William E.
[[Category:Accounting source documents]] [[Category:Health insurance in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Nihongo|'''Tokumei kumiai'''|匿名組合}}, literally "anonymous partnerships," are a [[Japan]]ese [[bilateral contract]] governed by the Commercial Code of Japan, Article 535 ''et seq''.<ref name="art535">[http://ja.wikibooks.org/wiki/%E5%95%86%E6%B3%95%E7%AC%AC535%E6%9D%A1 Japanese Commercial Code, article 535]</ref> In English, they are often called '''TK''' or '''silent partnerships'''. In many respects they are similar to [[common law]] [[limited partnership]]s.
In a tokumei kumiai arrangement, {{Nihongo|"anonymous (or silent) partners"|匿名組合員|tokumei kumiai'in}} invest in a venture operated by a {{Nihongo|manager|営業者|eigyōsha}}.<ref name="art535" />
By law, the partnership itself has no [[Juristic person|legal personality]]. Any assets of the partnership are the property of the manager; however, the anonymous partners have a right to a share of any profits from the venture, as provided in the partnership agreement. Anonymous partners have [[limited liability]] for the partnership's debts, on the condition that they are anonymous. If an anonymous partner allows their name to be used in the name of the manager or in the name of the partnership, the anonymous partner loses their limited liability.<ref>[http://ja.wikibooks.org/wiki/%E5%95%86%E6%B3%95%E7%AC%AC536%E6%9D%A1 Japanese Commercial Code, article 536]</ref>
Tokumei kumiai are often used for investment funds. A structure known as the "Dutch TK" was once popular among foreign investors in Japan, as it was possible to recognize income from Japan through a Dutch anonymous partner in a tokumei kumiai without paying Japanese income or withholding taxes under the tax treaty of 1970. This loophole was closed by a new tax treaty in August 2010, which imposes a 20% withholding tax on distributions through such structures.<ref>http://www.taxand.com/news/newsletters/New_Dutch_Japanese_Tax_Treaty_Signed_Benefits_Investors</ref> More recently, it has become popular to use a tokumei kumiai together with a [[godo kaisha]] to hold a [[Land trust|trust]] [[beneficial interest]] in real estate using what is known as a "TK/GK scheme."<ref>{{cite web|title=Amendment To The Japanese Real Estate Joint Enterprise Act: Will It Benefit Overseas Investors?|url=http://mondaq.com/x/254384/real+estate/Amendment+to+the+Japanese+Real+Estate+Joint+Enterprise+Act+Will+It+Benefit+Overseas+Investors|publisher=[[Jones Day]]|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==See also== *[[Limited liability partnership]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tokumei Kumiai}} [[Category:Japanese business terms]] [[Category:Japanese business law]] [[Category:Partnerships]]

'''Tony Trahar''' (born 1949 in Johannesburg, South Africa) is a [[South Africa]]n businessman and former chairman of [[Anglo American (mining)|Anglo American]].
Trahar was educated at [[St John's College (Johannesburg, South Africa)|St John's College]] and the [[University of the Witwatersrand]], after which he qualified as a [[chartered accountant]].
He joined [[Anglo American (mining)|Anglo American]] in 1974 and later was an assistant to [[Gavin Relly]] and was appointed finance director in 1982. Trahar became the managing director of Anglo American's paper company, Mondi, in 1986. He succeeded [[Julian Ogilvie Thompson]] as CEO of Anglo American in 2000.
Trahar stepped down as chairman and CEO in 2007, succeeded by [[Cynthia Carroll]].
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061224204625/http://www.miningmx.com/profiles/320962.htm Profiles of Anglo American chief executives]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=December 2011}} {{COI|date=August 2010}} {{Advert|date=October 2015}} }}
Part of the [[Thomson Reuters]] Risk Management Solutions suite, the '''World-Check''' [[database]] of [[Politically exposed person|Politically Exposed Persons]] (PEPs) and heightened risk individuals and organisations is used around the world to help to identify and manage financial, regulatory and reputational risk.
The creation of the database was in response to legislation aimed at reducing the incidence of [[financial crimes]]. To begin with, World-Check's intelligence was used by banks and financial institutions as a comprehensive solution for assessing, managing and remediating risk. However, as legislation has become increasingly complex and its reach has become increasingly global, the demand for such intelligence has grown beyond the financial sector to include organisations from all sectors.
== Research coverage == World-Check's research team monitors emerging risks in more than 60 languages, covering over 240 countries and territories worldwide. All information used is in the public domain and research analysts profile individuals and entities using open-source research methodology ([[OSINT]]) while adhering to strict protocol such as that laid down by the [[Data Protection Act 1998|Data Protection Act]] (UK).
In 2011, World-Check received independent assurance under the International Standard on Assurance Engagements ([[ISAE 3000]]) for the internal processes and controls that govern its global sanctions platform and dataset.
A dedicated team of research analysts correlates sanction and embargo lists from around the world, including lists such as OFAC, UK HMT, EU, OSFI, FATF and the Australian DFAT. Regulatory and enforcement lists are monitored as well as lists of debarred and banned parties.
Specific areas of interest, such as terrorism, organised crime and the [[Middle East]], are covered by specialist research teams.
==About World-Check==
Registered in [[London]], World-Check was founded in 2000 by David Leppan to address the risk mitigation requirements of the Swiss banking community. During 2008, World-Check launched Country-Check, an index that ranks over 240 countries and territories worldwide in terms of risk. A statistical algorithm is used to aggregate various information sources across political, financial and criminal factors and this quantifies risk attached to customers and transactions according to their country of origin. Based on statistics and not perception, Country-Check provides practical intelligence for informed decision-making, useful for mergers and acquisitions, security of supply chain, cross border expansion and exploration, and production.
In 2009 World-Check increased its offering by acquiring IntegraScreen, a provider of enhanced due diligence reporting services. IntegraScreen reports are used when a detailed background check on any entity or individual is required, and research can be carried out no matter where the location.
== Leak of Database and Security Compromises == In a reddit post, a user declared that he had acquired a copy of the World-Check database with information up to 2014. This leak online apparently was possible due to an incomplete assessment of the security, and was downloaded through the website Shodan, a search engine that lets the user find specific types of computers connected to the internet using a variety of filters, raising questions about the allegedly privacy and security of the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/privacy/comments/4q840n/terrorism_blacklist_i_have_a_copy_should_it_be/:|title=Terrorism Blacklist: I have a copy. Should it be shared? • r/privacy|website=reddit}}</ref>
==False claims== ===PSC=== In 2017, World-Check admitted that the Palestine Solidarity Campaign (PSC) should never have been placed on their database at all and, specifically, should not have been associated with "terrorism", stressing that there were no grounds to suggest that PSC were either associated with terrorism related activity or that the organisation presented any kind of financial risk. The PSC and World-Check have reached an agreement to address the harm done to the reputation of the PSC and its chair, Mr. Hugh Lanning, and to resolve the matters between them arising from that profile.<ref>http://imemc.org/article/palestine-solidarity-campaign-removed-from-world-check-terrorist-listing/</ref>
===Finsbury Park Mosque=== World-Check was forced to pay compensation and apologise to [[Finsbury Park Mosque]] in 2017 after falsely claiming that it had a current association with terrorism.<ref>{{cite news|title=Van attack shatters calm at mosque with a troubled history|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d31780c4-550a-11e7-9fed-c19e2700005f|accessdate=21 June 2017|publisher=Financial Times|date=20 June 2017}}</ref>
== Thomson Reuters ==
In 2011, [[Thomson Reuters]] acquired World-Check as a key component of their Governance Risk and Compliance (GRC) unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://risk.thomsonreuters.com/|title=English|website=Thomson Reuters}}</ref>
== See also == *[[World Leaders]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://risk.thomsonreuters.com/products/world-check World-Check] by [[Thomson-Reuters]] * [http://www.isae3000.com/ ISAE 3000 Compliance, sustainability and outsourcing audit assurance standard] * [http://gsw.global/en/spotlight GSW Spotlight: PEPs, DEbarred persons & Blacklisting Screening Service] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02z7yf3 BBC Documentary: Bank Account Bans]
{{Thomson Reuters}}
[[Category:Thomson Reuters]] [[Category:Open-source intelligence]] [[Category:Companies established in 2000]] [[Category:Political databases]]

{{Infobox person | name = Yousif bin Abdulrahman bin Abdulla bin Hassan bin Mahmood Fakhro | image = الوجيه يوسف بن عبدالرحمن الحسن الفخرو.jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = Portrait of Yousif Fakhro | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 1871 | birth_place = [[Muharraq]], Bahrain | death_date = 1952 | death_place = Bahrain | nationality = [[Bahrain]]i | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} [[File:وثيقة كتبت عام 1920 إلى الوجيه يوسف بن عبدالرحمن الحسن آل فخروه..jpg|262px|thumbnail|A document sent in the year 1920 A.D. to Yusuf bin Abdul-Rahman Al-Hassan Al Fakhro.]]
'''Yousif bin Abdulrahman Al-Hassan Al-Fakhro''' (Arabic: يَوسف بن عَبدالرحمن بن عَبدالله آل حسن آل فخرو) (lived 1871–1952), also known as '''Yousif Al Oud''', was one of the most prominent and wealthiest [[businessman|businessmen]] in [[Bahrain]].
==Biography== He owned more than fifty ships ([[dhow]]s) that roamed the [[Persian Gulf]] and the [[Indian Ocean]], with offices in Bahrain, [[Basra]], [[India]], [[Kuwait]] and [[Dubai]], and established what is known today as the [[Fakhro Group]], a diversified family business based in Bahrain.
He was known to finance the government of Bahrain at the time and the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] army.
He was one of the few businessmen that filled in to establish the first school in Bahrain in 1919, [[Al-Hidaya Al-Khalifiya]].
==Children== He had five sons: * Ahmed (died 1979) * Mohammad (died 1989) * Abdulla (died 2001) * Ibrahim (died 2001) * [[Ali bin Yousif Fakhro]] (died 2008)
He also had eight daughters.
==External links== * http://alfakhro.net/family/images/stories/men/yousuf%20abd%20fakhro.jpg
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fakhro, Yousif bin Abdulrahman}} [[Category:1871 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:Bahraini businesspeople]]
